reviewText:
One of the best games ever. Like masturbating with a woman. 10/10 ---

If you play with Windows 7 x64x32 or Win 8/8.1 x64x32, you <<have to>> patch from 1.5 to Version 1.7, <<and>> add this two Lines to the config File:

(Start the game at least one time before searching for the ini. It will create itself after the first start of the game)

My Documents\My Games\Fallout3\Fallout3.ini
----------------------------------------------------------------
Find: bUseThreadedAI=0
Change it to: bUseThreadedAI=1
add below (new line):
iNumHWThreads=2
----------------------------------------------------------------
If you do so, you should have no freezing problems.
__________________________________________

Pls lilke this review, if you think everybody should enjoy this awsome game. Because i read plenty of negative reviews, complaining about freezing and crashing. but it´s very easy to fix!






Eines der besten Spiele je Produziert. 10/10 ----

(Einmal das Spiel starten. Die Konfig File erstellt sich nach dem ersten Spielstart von selbst. Vorher sucht man vergeblich)

Meine Dokumente\My Games\Fallout3\Fallout3.ini
----------------------------------------------------------------
Finde: bUseThreadedAI=0
ändere es zu: bUseThreadedAI=1
füge darunter hinzu(neue Zeile):
iNumHWThreads=2
----------------------------------------------------------------
Wenn du das machst, solltest du keine Systemabstürtze mehr im Spiel haben.
__________________________________________

reviewText:
Probably one of my favourite games of all time. Stepping out of the vault into the harsh sun drenched wasteland is a moment in my gaming history that I will never quite forget. The thrill of seeing this open world stretching off to the horizon, knowing that adventure awaited me, left me almost awe struck.

The game itself is a totally open game where you can chose your own path in a Post Apocalyptic hell hole. Will you be a heroic saviour of mankind, or a vicious survivor who does what is needed to survive? It is completely up to you. On your way you will meet a mix of people, some evil, some less so, and others .. well let's just say the wasteland produces a lot of strange characters.

A great game, but made even greater by the modding community that has been built up around it. This is one of those games I highly recommend modding pretty much immediately. And if you have any worries about doing so, check out my tutorials for modding this game: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-SAeXsA6Nt8&index=5&list=PL77ECC4B6194E1685

Be warned however that this game is old, and will need quite a lot of tweaking to get working on Windows 7 or later. If you also own Fallout: New Vegas, I would actually recommend using the Tales of Two Wastelands mod to play the Fallout 3 story using the Fallout: New Vegas engine, which is far more stable and works fine on Windows 7.

I have no tutorial on this mod yet, but when I do, I will update this review.

IMPORTANT: I have played this game for several hundred hours, but not on this account, and most with certain mods installed that stop Steam from knowing that I was playing.

reviewText:
This game is like a girlfriend.
You meet, fall in love and have a blast when you spend time with her, especially when your exploring dark subway tunnels, if you know what i mean. She looks gorgeous all of the time and always does her best to keep you entertained for hours and hours and hours on end, she has a really nice and amazing futuristic 1950's style to her that no one could hate and she has some really good taste in music too!

Sure, she has a few issues, she takes her time getting ready and sometimes when she is getting ready she will just stop getting ready and go to sleep until you wake her up again. She wont even talk to you or respond to you in anyway if you own a Windows 7 operating system but that can be fixed easily, you just have to convince her that its not all bad and then she will come around!

If you break up with her, you will always find yourself coming back to her and she wont even judge you, she will act like she always did before you split up with her, and everytime you do come back the experience you have with her again is amazing and diffirent to the last time

Buy this game, its an experience you will never forget!

Fallout was there for me when I started high school.
Fallout was there for me when I lost my mother.
Fallout was there for me when I fell into depression.
Fallout was there for me when I graduated high school.
Fallout was there for me when I fell in love.
Fallout was there for me when I was cheated on.
Fallout was there for me when I recovered.
Fallout was there for me always.
Fallout is love, Fallout is life.

reviewText:
I found a dog in the middle of junkyard and it started to follow me. I took that dog everywhere and we became best buddies. One day, I got into a nasty firefight and was worried for my newfound friend so, I yelled at him to run away. I survived the firefight, with the help of a few dozen stimpaks, and I returned to Vault 101 in search of my dog.

I returned to the Vault and didn't see a sign of my friend. I was worried and waited for hours on end. He was nowhere to be found. I was so worried. Sadly, this story doesn't end well. I never saw the dog again and I know that somewhere in the Wasteland lies a dead dog. Knowing this, I began to cry.

10/10 for making me feel for a digital dog

reviewText:
Excellent game.
100% working on my Windows 8 64-bit system.
Only limitation is impossibility to recover back after keys Alt + Tab.
Note: there is no Steam achievements.


Step 1 obligatory
Start Fallout, click Play, push the escape key and Quit.
It will validate your game, detect your graphics card and create a fallout.ini.

=======================
Step 2 if needed
IF CRASHING WHEN CLICKING PLAY"
Fallout 3 has an error that says "Ordinal 42 could not be found in the Dynamic Link Library" or something related to "Xlive.dll".
This error message comes up when you do not have Games for Windows Live installed on your computer. You can download that client here: http://www.xbox.com/en-US/live/pc/DownloadClient Note
date: you will not be able to make any other use of the service at this time.\n\nIf that doesn't work
recommended: click "options" and set your resolution to your desktop res
hoursPlayed:
or try windowed mode.
======================
Step 3 if needed (I did not needed it)
As Fallout 3 was created prior to the release of Windows 7 and 8
voteText: it is not tested or supported on either of these newer operating systems. There are
helpfulPercent: however
votesHelpful: a few workarounds that players can use to run the game.\n\nFirst
votesTotal:
you may be able to run it using compatibility mode. To change compatibility settings for Fallout 3:
1.Locate the application file for the game. This can be found in one of the following folders depending on which version of the game you use:
◦Retail versions: C:\Program Files (x86)\Bethesda Softworks\Fallout 3
◦Steam versions: C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\Steamapps\Common\Fallout 3

2.Right-click on the application file and select Properties.
3.Click on the Compatibility tab.
4.Check the box Run this program in compatibility mode.
5.Choose Windows XP Service Pack 3 from the drop-down.
6.It may also be necessary to check the box for Run this program as an administrator.
7.Repeat steps 2-6 for the Fallout 3 launcher file in the same folder. It is labeled: FalloutLauncher
8.Run the game.

======================
Step 3 important
Fallout 3 was not developed for use on PCs with more than two cores. If your PC has more than two cores
votesFunny: please try the following steps:\n1.Open your My Documents folder.\n2.Under My Games
commentsCount: open the Fallout 3 folder and select the fallout.ini file.\n3.In the fallout.ini file
column16:
find the following line: bUseThreadedAI=0
4.Change this line to read: bUseThreadedAI=1
5.Add another line after it that reads: iNumHWThreads=2
6.Run the game.

======================
Step 4 Optional but strongly recommended!
Unofficial Fallout 3 Patch
TONS of bug fixes. It would take dozens of pages to list them all.
* The site registration for Nexus is free and quick.
Patch v1.8 (1 November 2014)

reviewText:
Imagine yourself in a world that consists of daily routine and hard work. A small room for your house and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for your neighbors. You dont know what lies beyond the safety of… The Vault. Fallout 3 takes you on a never seen before adventure in a videogame that still shocks and awes people today. With one of the largest maps in a videogame and 5 DLC’s, fallout 3 brings the post-apocalyptic future, from books and movies to life where you are the main character. with 100’s of quests and people, Fallout 3 is an amazingly fun game to explore.

It takes place in the post-apocalyptic washington D.C. which has 100’s of streets and even more metro tunnels. With everything from compounds to abandon buildings, you will come across everything from raiders to town dwellers to the enclave and more!

Ok, now for the numbers:

Graphics: 7.5/10 This is not concerning although because of new mods coming out daily for new experiences.

Controls: (Pc) 7/10 and (xbox controller) 10/10. Buy a controller for this game, it is worth it.

Handling: 9/10. A very smooth game.

Story: 8/10. Story ha its moments and It's just ok. But the side quests where very good and a few DLC's where amazing like Mothership Zeta.

Gameplay: 8/10. Falls short a bit compared to the rest of the game but it still has great moments, especially in the DLC’s.

Creativity: 8/10. Never done before… in a videogame.

Price: 10+/10. $20 in DLC with the game for only $20 full price. I have over 300 hours on this game and still i got it for $5 on sale!!! DO NOT TURN AWAY BECAUSE OF THE PRICE!!!

Hype: 10/10. Enough said.

Overall: 9/10. BUY BUY BUY!

reviewText:
Let me tell you all a story.

I was once the Fresh Prince the Vault, and then my dad, Liam Neeson, left Vault 101. This is what happened after I went after him.

-Found a demonic mining company with Cthulhu references abound.
-Disarmed an atomic bomb.
-Saved a group of rangers from death-by-super-mutant.
-Gave some homeless people water (purified, no less).
-Shot a military colonel in the face.
-Met a talking tree, of all things.
-Got a friendly super mutant companion.
-Retook Anchorage.
-Traveled to Pittsbur- I mean The Pitt.
-Went down south to ♥♥♥♥thatville, also known as Point Lookout.
-Got abducted and probed by aliens.

And the one your all waiting for...

-I knew how to swim after being stuck underground for 19 years with no swimming pool and/or body of water.

10/10

Seeing as this review has gotten much more popular than I expected, I would like to say a few things.
Firstly, regardless of what Steam says, I have over one thousand hours in this game. I previously played on Xbox, and I haven`t really started a PC run.
I wholly reccomend this to anyone wanting to play a game with great rpg, as this game is fun even five years after it`s original release. I strongly reccommend getting the DLC, as it adds a lot of content. Even with all those hours on a completely vanilla game, I still don`t believe I explored everything, and there were many, many areas I had yet to visit.
Personal score: This is one of the best games I`ve ever played

reviewText:
Gameplay is excellent. I've heard some complaints about the combat but i thought it was great. The V.A.T.S gives you a really cool tactical shooter perspective.The Animations are a bit akward and theres no sprinting which should be ESSENTIAL because the world is so vast. This is nothing that mods couldn't fix. The leveling system is amazing in which you can choose which skills you want to master based on your playstyle.

Visuals:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=441989686
The visuals are alright. It's something you would expect since it was released in 2008. I thought the visuals were pretty good and nailed the vibe but looked a bit bland. I installed a few mods to fix this. If your computer can handle them i suggest modding the ♥♥♥♥ out of this game graphically.

Audio:

The audio of this game is AMAZING. The soundtrack fits right into the retro 50's post apocalyptic setting. Having the in game radio on at all times is a REQUIREMENT to fully enjoy this game.

Environment:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=441989678
The environment in this game is big but not huge. It's an open world game much like Skyrim is. The map is filled with sidequest you can do for awesome rewards like laser guns or awesome launchers that launch 6 nukes at a time and causes an a explosion so big it might crash your game and make GTX Titan Z's cry.

Optimization:

This game is not very well optimized for Windows 7,8. But there are solutions on the internet that will fix the game for the most part. During my 60 hours the game crashed about 11 times. around 7 of those were in one of the DLC's(Point Lookout) which is almost unplayable due to low framerate and crashing.

Verdict:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=441062483
This game is hands down one of the best games i have played and this a must buy for any video game fan. Even tho i put 60 hours into this i've barely scratched the surface since i have 3 full DLC's and their respective sidequest and half the sidequest in the main game to complete. After this i am definetly gonna definitely gonna pick up Fallout: New Vegas

reviewText:
Warning: Disliking this game is punishable by death.

Methods of execution include getting beaten to death by drug-crazed raiders, blown apart by explosive weapons, turned into ash by one of the many laser weapons used here, and dying slowly and horribly from radiation poisoning. Fun! But all of these execution methods are, ultimately, better than becoming a communist. As Liberty Prime so eloquently puts it: better dead than red.

Seriously though. Dislike this game and I will personally call a vertibird strike on your ♥♥♥. You have been warned. o_O

The first Fallout game by Bethesda is noticeably different in tone from the old Fallout games, and particularly Fallout 2. This is one of the bleakest and most depressing games I've ever played, depicting a world that is in far worse shape than any other Fallout game where there are at least some signs of civilization returning. Here... everything is either dead or slowly dying as it is consumed by non-stop violence and pervasive radiation. How lovely. x_x

The most logical explanation for this, aside from the change in developer, is that whereas the previous Fallout games centered on the West Coast of the USA with only a few major cities (Los Angeles/The Boneyard in Fallout 1, San Francisco in Fallout 2) showing up in relatively small roles in the plot, Fallout 3 centers on Washington DC, the US capital (as well as Pittsburgh, PA in a DLC). A city that, in any nuclear war, would be a primary target for destruction, and that destruction is very much on display in a disturbing amount of detail. As someone who has visited DC three times in my life at the time of writing, the last of which occuring about a week after I first played this game (January 2009), strolling around the ruins of a place I have seen in the real world is really eerie. Almost every major landmark in DC can be visited in Fallout 3, except now they are all in various stages of ruin (The Washington Monument is more or less intact, while the White House is just a massive radioactive crater) and filled with ceaseless violence.

If you have played Bethesda's other open-world RPG's like Oblivion or Skyrim, then you know how this plays: lots of quests and stuff to do, but mostly its about running around a huge world and seeing what you find. There are some glitches and crashes, so be sure to save often. GFWL is part of this, but you can tell that to bugger off pretty easily (and in fact you need to in order to use the best mods). Also while it might take a little work to get mods working, they are more than worth the effort. The superb mods for New Vegas and Skyrim found on the Nexus Network websites can be traced back to Fallout 3 mods, and many have the same creators (Fallout 3's FWE later became New Vegas' Project Nevada). In other words, this game has insane replay value by itself, and modding Fallout 3 can turn this into a game with virtually endless amounts of things to do.

The GOTY version includes the five DLC's, which are a mixed bag of awesome, competence, and failure. Broken Steel is probably the best since it allows you to play after the end of the main story, along with the host of additional content it adds. The Pitt is a dark atmospheric journey into the industrial ruins of Pittsburgh filled with gray morality and disturbing choices. Point Lookout sends you into a similarly immersive swamp area with lots to explore and one of the most memorable (and by far the foulest-mouthed) characters in the Fallout series. But the other two DLC, Operation Anchorage's linear adventure into a simulation of a great battle before the apocalypse (It's ok) and Mothership Zeta's killing spree through an alien spaceship (ugh...), fall far below the other three in quality. Regardless, all of them add more to the game and give you plenty of new toys to use in the main game.

I've heard this game has some issues with Win7 and newer operating systems, but I don't know anything about that since I'm still using the same PC I used when I first played this game so many years ago. I do believe there are fixes, but people with those newer OS's should look into them before buying this (or just get it on sale)

Regardless of its bugs and other issues that keep it from being perfect, this is one of my favorite games of all time, and that's really all you need to know. Buy it. Play it. Like it. Or else I will call you a communist and point Libery Prime your way.

Communism is the very definition of failure. :P

reviewText:
This is a great game from Bethdesda, it was the first I played in the series and it was a brilliant Survival Horror style First-Person Open-World Role-Playing Game. (SHFPSOWRPG).

If you even remoteley enjoyed or found interest in games like Skyrim, Fallout: New Vegas or other titles from Bethdesda, this one is VERY MUCH WORTH IT. The narrative is great, the main story can be completed in about a few hours, but if you roam the world and try to explore, interact and enjoy it then it will take well over decades for you to finish it. If you ever manage to finish all the sidequests, storylines, locate all the places on the map, experience all the random events and meet all the intriguing characters and learn of stories in the past or present gameworld; then you can play the DLCs, Broken Steel, Operation: Anchorage, Point Lookout and Mothership Zeta. The DLCs accumulate up to even more hours of main quests, not to ignore the fact they add new locations and maybe even a whole new part of the game world.

TL;DR: Get this game, it is ♥♥♥♥ing brilliant you slacker.

-Stario

reviewText:
Fallout 3... Where to start....

This is the game that introduced me into RPG games.
It was and will always be my favourite game.

The interesting things in the games lore, the places, the people, the weapons. All so perfect. And the DLC makes it even more God Tier.

I've played more than this steam review will say. I own it on Console and the retail disk copy and i am proud to own it again on steam.

There is no way you can get bored in this game. If you run out of Quests. The modding community is there for you. So many possiblities and mods that make it amazing.

This is the most amazing game i have played. Full stop. No recent games have even gotten near Fallout on my list. It's just so bloody perfect.

Buy it if you don't have it. Get GOTY if you can. You won't regret it.

Oh and for those who say they have problems with Windows 7. I use Windows 7. It's called Google and the Modding community. I suggest you actually look around a bit.

I give it a strong 9.5/10.

reviewText:
Just to clarify with you, I have been playing Fallout 3 ever since I was ten years old (yes, a ten year old played this game). I remember begging my mom for it day after day ever since the first day it was released. When I saw that lunchbox (collector's edition) shaped present under my tree, I opened it instantaneously and saw my dream present. I ran up to my room, launched it on my Xbox 360, and experienced one of the best things I had ever seen/played in my life. I think that overall, I have accumulated over 1200 hours playing this one game, so now you know that I have some experience with it. Moving on to the review...

*By the way, I wrote this review as a huge piece, but I decided to divide it up with headers if you want to learn about a specific aspect only.


INTRO and CHARACTER CREATION
Fallout 3 is set in a post-apocalyptic version of Washington, DC. You are a resident living in Vault 101, one of the many underground shelters built by a company named 'Vault-Tec' before the bombs dropped in America on October 23, 2077.  About 200 years later, the game starts you off with a thirty minute prologue. You begin right at birth where you create your character's appearance and eventually set his/her's S.P.E.C.I.A.L. attributes and your TAG skills. If you played the original Fallout or Wasteland games, you will be very familiar with the character creation system. Basically, you have 33 points to work around with that can be placed in Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck and you will excel or be weaker in certain areas depending on where you allocate these points. TAG skills on the other hand raise three of your skills by +15 to give you boosts in certain areas when you start off.


PLOT/STORY and QUESTS
In the beginning of your life, everything is fairly normal in the vault. You are raised by your single-dad, James (voiced by Liam Neeson), and deal with the usual experiences of childhood such as birthday parties, friendships, bullies, and school. Once you reach the segment when you are nineteen years old (five segments at ages 0, 1, 10, 16, and 19), things start to go wild when your dad leaves Vault 101 without you. Naturally, you decide to escape the vault yourself to find dear old Dad and discover why he left and where you can find him. Along the way, you will run into extremely diverse characters ranging from a grizzled man who is the sheriff of a town centered on an undetonated atomic bomb, a ghoul-hating, deceptive old geezer who owns a refurbished hotel, a psychotic, Russian pimp who is willing to sell his women's services" to anyone who has enough caps (currency)
date: and even aliens. I won't say anything more about the plot
hoursPlayed: Fallout 3 has a very personal main quest that will pull your heart strings on numerous occasions.\n\nAccompanied by the main quests are an insane amount of side quests that will lead you to the many interesting settlements across the Capital Wasteland. They range from simple assassination and extortion missions all the way to solving a crisis between two "superheroes" disrupting a town or managing a cannibal situation. Whenever you play Fallout 3
voteText:
your quest tab in the Pip-Boy 3000 will always have at least something in it for you to complete and you will never be left empty handed - especially with the amazing mods out there (I will get into that later).


USER INTERFACE
Speaking of the Pip-Boy
helpfulPercent: it is your main user-interface while playing. With the press of a button
votesHelpful: your status
votesTotal: karma
votesFunny: missions
commentsCount: map
column16: items
column17: notes
column18: and radio will all be easily accessible to you. It is a great
column19:
clean interface that makes everything very manageble for the player.


SOUNDTRACK
One thing that is easily overlooked with Fallout 3 is its incredible soundtrack. All of the music is from the early-mid 20th century and it perfectly fits the atmosphere of the game. Eventually
column20: you will know many of the songs note for note and for some reason
column21: I have not gotten tired of the music six years later. However
column22: the ambient soundtrack is another huge strength for the game. When you are exploring the Capital Wasteland without the radio playing on your Pip-Boy
column23:
you will get to hear the creepy atmospheric music play in the background. It will build up the suspense in you and keep you always on the lookout for any nearby threats. The combat music is good too and it will make encounters feel more deadly and action-packed.


GAMEPLAY
As for the gameplay

column30: but once again it can be removed using mods (we are getting there :P) and it is not a big deal. There are a variety of guns in the game that range from the categories of small guns (pistols

column39: you will enjoy it in Fallout 3. You can go unarmed or use a bladed or blunt weapon.\n\nWeapons are not the only things to consider in Fallout 3. Secondary skills like repair
column41: and speech all carry just as much weight as the combat skills. It is even possible to make characters that focus exclusively on non-combat skills and have hireable companions do all the killing for you. This is the beauty of the Fallout games
column42: any character build can be viable as long as you do what is necessary to make it work.\n\nAs you progress throughout the game your character gains xp by completing tasks like killing
column48: and more. When you reach the xp requirement to advance in level

you can allocate your skill points (amount of skill points determined by intelligence) to any of the thirteen skills accessible to you. This does not follow the "practice makes perfect" levelling module that The Elder Scrolls uses.


MODS
This is the big one that you have been waiting for! The Fallout 3 nexus (fallout3.nexusmods.com) at this moment contains 13 526 files available to download for free to enhance your Fallout 3 experience
column50: and the number grows daily. Just about anything can be tweaked or created by using the Garden of Eden Creation Kit

column56: which can greatly add to the experience. These mods are excellent and add many things that should have been in the game to begin with. Just be warned

column60: and can be incompatibile with other mods. For your first playthrough I would highly recommend downloading strictly fixes and tweaks like the Updated Unofficial Fallout 3 Patch
column64: and texture mods. You could even download FWE
column65: but I would 100% go to the preset options once you exit the vault in the FWE control panel and use the 'I Love Vanilla' preset to keep the original feel of the game. When you are done with your first playthrough of the vanilla game
column66: go ahead and add in all the mods you want! Just make sure you know what you are doing and if you don't
column67:
follow Gopher's EXCEPTIONAL 'Fallout 3 Modding Guide' on Youtube.



CONCLUSION

reviewText:
****
4 out of 5
Expansive, awesome and beautiful. Fallout 3 is what RPGs aspire to.

Featuring a long absence from the 90s classics Fallout 1 and 2, Bethesda Softworks brings back Fallout for a new generation. Awaking in an apocalyptic nightmare, your own hope to survive in this new world is to explore, upgrade and befriend or back-stab as many people as you can.

Fallout 3 is a gorgeously realised game not only in its visuals, but the narrative, its atmosphere and the unremarkable but noticable human touches throughout.

Fallout 3 is one to recommend, albeit you can find yourself wandering through a carbon copy of the same underground tunnel or factory at times, but that's nothing to greatly disservice such a great experience.

reviewText:
Still an unoptimized relic that will be sold to a world that has long since left Microsoft Vista and Games For Windows Live in the trash bin of history. Fallout 3 is the quintessential Bethesda game which puts the burden of functionality directly onto the consumer to mod the game into some shape that doesn't crash as soon as combat begins, even if it’s altering one line of code in the ini file.

The qualities of game mechanics and story are nothing without the ability to run on a machine and operating system built after 2008. When GOG and Lucasarts/Disney patch the likes of KOTOR 2 or older games into something that can easily run decades after their initial release, Betheda should be able to hire coders to take out GWFL with their Fallout Shelter war chest alone.

reviewText:
Bethesda should've patched this version better on Win7 or Win8.
It IS a classic and has made so many revenue so you!!!

Down vote until a better patch is out.


------------------

For now, you have to do the following thing from the link:
http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/20371/?tab=2&navtag=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nexusmods.com%2Ffallout3%2Fajax%2Fmodfiles%2F%3Fid%3D20371&pUp=1


------------------

Making Fallout 3 work on Windows 7 & 8

Getting Fallout 3 to run on win 7 and 8

Step 1: Copy the D3D9.dll from the “Source Files” Folder into the main Fallout 3 Directory (Not the Data directory)

Step 2: Right click on the “FalloutLauncher.exe” and “Fallout3.exe” and go to properties.

Step 3: For both “FalloutLauncher.exe” and “Fallout3.exe” right click and go to properties and set the compatibility mode to Windows XP (Service Pack 3)

MAKE SURE THAT FALLOUT 3 IS NOT OPEN FOR THE NEXT STEPS
Fallout 3 Config File Editing

Before you try below copy the “Fallout_Default.ini“ file included in the “Source FIles” Folder and place it into your Fallout Directory (NOT THE DATA ONE)

Manually Editing the config file if the above doesn't work.
Step 1: Open up the Configuration file in Notepad in the fallout 3 directory, (Which should be named Fallout_default") press Ctrl+F and find the following line of text. NOTE: THIS IS CASE SENSITIVE

bUseThreadedAI=0

You must change this to:

bUseThreadedAI=1

Step 3: Directly underneath the changed line of text
date:
create a new line and type:

iNumHWThreads=2

Step 4: Save the config file and then close. Then try to launch Fallout 3.

These steps are basically telling the game to launch using just 2 cores. This way it will make sure that the game will not freeze due to errors trying to find 'outdated' cores.

This fix will usually solve your problems
recommended: however if this has not worked and the game is still crashing then try these additional steps:\n\n-Uninstall Fallout 3
hoursPlayed: disable .NET 3.1 under 'Turn windows features On or Off'
voteText:
then reinstall.

-Renaming or deleting the music folder inside the Fallout 3 folder apparently helps as well somehow?

Now it should work

reviewText:
ENGLISH and Italian Review  Recensione Inglese ed ITALIANA

War... war never changes.

English:

Don't trust my gametime, i've bought this game on Steam too, just for collection. This game literally ruined my life, i've finished it like 14 times before losing the count. No, i'm not crazy, yes, my social life imploded. And don't trust the grandpas that will tell you this game is garbage just because they played the first 2 Fallouts and refused to play this one, they are just ignorant. In this game you live a wonderful and touching adventure in first person (Identifying so with the character), watching the character growing and becoming the hero or anti-hero that he'll be. Oh yes, because obviously you can and have to choose between choices that will influence the events and your karma. So, we have an abnormus replay factor, if we consider that we can play as good, bad, neutrals or do a mixed playtrough, choosing maybe a different type of class for the fight. AND, the game is easily moddable and has a large and active modding community: Nexus Mods. So, even if you have finished it in every way possible, you can mod it and transform it in a new game to discover. Trust me, this game is AWESOME.


La guerra... la guerra non cambia mai.

Italiano:

Non fidatevi del tempo di gioco che dice Steam, l'ho comprato anche qui giusto per averlo. Questo gioco ha letteralmente rovinato la mia vita, lo avrò finito qualcosa come 14 volte prima di perdere il conto. No, non sono pazzo, si, la mia vita sociale ne ha risentito un pochino. E non fidatevi dei vecchiacci che vi diranno che questo titolo fa schifo, solo perché giocarono ai primi due ai tempi, e si rifiutarono di giocare questo, sono degli ignoranti. In questo gioco vivi un'avventura stupenda e toccante in prima persona (Immedesimandoti dunque nel personaggio), vedendo il personaggio crescere man mano e plasmandolo lentamente nell'eroe o antieroe che sarà. Eh si, perché ovviamente potrai e dovrai fare delle scelte che influenzeranno gli eventi ed il tuo karma. Abbiamo dunque anche un fattore rigiocabilità enorme se consideriamo che possiamo giocare da cattivi, da buoni, da neutri o fare un mix, scegliendo magari anche una tipologia di personaggio diversa per quanto riguarda i combattimenti. Senza contare il fatto che il gioco è facilmente moddabile e vanta di una community di modders vasta e attiva, ovvero Nexus Mods. Dunque anche avendolo finito in tutte le maniere possibili e immaginabili, potete ancora moddarlo all'infinito e renderlo un gioco nuovo tutto da riscoprire. Fidatevi, questo gioco è perfetto.

reviewText:
I'd like to start this review by saying that Fallout 3 is an absolutely magnificent beast of a game and that it will remain one of my most beloved games for ETERNITY. I first played the base game, without any DLC, and I'm very glad I did. This is primarily because even without any DLC, there are a plethora of locations to discover and explore, so many quests to do and plenty of people to help or hinder (or shoot in the face and rob). This review might be a bit long, but it is one of the few games I can play again and again, time after time, and still become 100% immersed in, so bear with me ;)
Some spoilers may lurk below, be warned!

First off, Fallout 3 is a single-player, post-apocalyptic game set in a post-nuclear American wasteland. As I touched upon earlier, the game world is gigantic, maybe even dauntingly so. I'm the type of gamer who has to discover everything, so for me this was a massive plus in the game's favour. This wanderlust is helped and even encouraged by a compass at the top of the screen, highlighting discovered and undiscovered locations. Once you're out into the wasteland proper, you're not really limited in where you can go, either. The amount of freedom this game gives you is refreshing and liberating, though be careful where you wander! As I found out, the answer to 'What's that thing over there running at high speed towards me?' is not 'let's go have a look', but instead 'it's a bloody great Deathclaw, and it's now chewing my face off, cheers wanderlust!'

Another point in F3's favour is that players can play in a way which suits them. Want to be a lovely guardian angel who wanders the wasteland helping others and destroying evil? Or would you be a horrible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that goes round pistol whipping people in the face? Do whatever you want, there's a variety of options you can take regarding playstyle. Also, while the range of options for offense/weaponry isn't as massive as some other games, there's still a very wide selection. Weapons can also be built once you've found the relevant schematics, some of which, without spoiling them, are very fun to play with. You can also experiment with different types of armour, or walk round in your pants, it's up to you really. The skills and perks systems allow you to choose whatever path you want, whether that involves big guns or slapping people about with melee weapons.

DLC aside, I was surprised at the relatively short length of the main questline in F3. For players who prefer to concentrate on the primary story arc, you may find the game ending somewhat prematurely. The full potential of this game really is unlocked when you take all of the side quests and exploring into account. The world is there to explore and it adds so, so much to the game. Some of the missions are downright crazy, while some locations are inherently creepy - I'm looking at you, creepy haunted place and acid-trip-gone-wrong Vault - and despite the length of the main arc, it is still an engaging storyline. I also found this game to be very immersive, especially when wearing headphones. You also have access to a radio through your Pip Boy device, and it's an oddly enjoyable experience wandering the wasteland listening to 'Jingle Jangle Jingle'.

The game is not without it's downsides however (though sometimes even they result in some classic moments). F3 will sometimes glitch out, and sometimes, it will glitch out spectacularly. The game incorporates a follower system, whereby some of the NPCs you meet in the game will agree to come and help you out, fighting monsters with you and the like; now I was wandering around with one of these followers and we happened to be walking next to those metal roadside barriers. I jumped over and ran on a little ways and turned round to make sure no beasties had snuck up on me, only to see my follower doing what appeared to be the Hokey Cokey dance on the barrier; before I could fully process this he was slingshotted into upper orbit, disappearing into the sky like a big green blob. It was okay though, he dithered out of the ether again about 10 minutes later, just in time to stop me getting done in by one of the wasteland's hostile denizens.

You may also find yourself randomly taking damage for no reason other than you trod on some clutter. Certain places in F3 are  immensely cluttered, meaning you will also at times be flung across a room as plungers apparently have a secondary function as trebuchets. When you're trying to sneak down a tunnel and not get your face shot off, suddenly treading on a cup and getting thrown into your assailants arms isn't much help. Also, if you've just left a crazy fight, uber low on health, and a wayward plate decides it hates your soul, you better prepare your ♥♥♥♥ because it's probably going to do you in if you stand on it in the wrong way.

While the ability to play this game however you want is a massive bonus, it also has its pitfalls. You can pretty much kill any NPC you find, and this can, at times, irrevocably screw up your game. F3 also has several console commands that you might use to help you out, such as using them to unlock a pesky door you keep failing to lockpick. Some of these commands can also screw the game up, so it pays to be mindful of what you're hammering into the console if that's something you enjoy exploring in a game.

Overall, I found Fallout 3 to be a wonderful game. It looks fantastic, and the post apocalyptic setting is rendered beautifully. The developers did a wonderful job here, and my only regret is that I didn't play it sooner. It also has so much replayability, you can come back to it again and again and make different choices, choose a different path. While it has its downsides, F3 makes up for them with an engaging world full of interesting characters and factions. It also helps that a lot of the bugs are hilarious and often don't have a massive impact on gameplay (I, for one, don't mind vanquished Mirelurks pinwheeling off into the sky). I do however think to get the full benefit of what this game has to offer, you have to pursue the side quests and get your explorer hat on. I also think that while I've reviewed the base game in general, the DLC adds a massive amount to the game and are well worth the money.

reviewText:
Great game, great characters. However there are a few flaws.

The first one is it's legendary instability under Windows 7 or later. Depending on your setup, the game can be anywhere between unplayable and crashing at the title screen to playable, but with scrambled music due to the Directsound kerfuffle. Heck, even though the game is playable under Vista the soundtrack is scrambled albeit still fixable if you're willing to go out and buy a Creative gaming sound card if just to use ALchemy to fix the soundtrack. The biggest issue is that Bethesda is not willing to fix the bugs even though there is a huge fanbase, and is even working against the fans by issuing takedowns at unofficial patches to fix the issues. That's right, the developer doesn't want fans to play the game with proper music.

Secondly, the game uses the problematic Games for Windows Live framework for a lot of things, including copy protection. Microsoft recently announced that they're shutting down GFWL. Guess what this means for the game. Sure, again there are fanmade patches to work around this, but well, it shows Bethesda's mindset.

In short, unless you're willing to go the full mile securing a decent Windows XP machine and then get your hands dirty with unofficial patches, don't buy this. If you absolutely must, get one of the console versions instead, PC gaming master race be damned. Don't get me wrong- It's a great game, and I support both consoles and PCs equally, but the PC version of this game is just not worth it and I'm not happy with the way Bethesda is treating the PC players of this game.

EDIT: Just bought a new laptop and upgraded it to Windows 10. Won't run, period. The game installs, the Launcher comes up (along with a stern warning from Windows saying that this game won't run), and... nothing. Clicking on Play results in nothing happening. Additionally, the game's installation of Games for Windows Live bricked the laptop's internet connection until said item is uninstalled. It has went from bad to worse. I definitey don't recommend it now. It's a great game, but it's coding is so bad it's not even forwards compatible with newer versions of Windows.

There is a fix that you can mess with the data file and add some text lines. This helps 99.9% of open world and LARGE" indoor area freezes. But it does nothing to Fix "SMALL" indoor area freezes. This includes "MAIN QUEST" small indoor areas and other nonmain quest small indoor areas. Making progress in the main story/quest nearly imposable.

If not for the freezes on windows 7/8. I would easily give this game an 11/10.

Yes I do still play this game (ignore my low time
date:
I don't play it threw steam).

But I have to give it a thumbs down. Due to the game braking freezes.
If you can do the fix (relatively easy) and deal with the extreme frustration of having the game freeze in critical areas/times and having to end task it then load it up again..........only to make it maybe 5 more secs in then having to do it all over again and again and again for small indoor areas. Then go for it. I do.

TL:DR
I love this game. But game breaking freezes on windows 7/8 keep me from giving it a thumbs up.

reviewText:
You are now entering the wasteland of fallout. Please enjoy your stay and make sure not to stick your hands out of the trolley. We do not like mutants.

As you see to your left these manhunters are the natural enemies of all living things they are called the death claws , they are quite deadly and remember to use VATS to target and aim for their vulnerable spots. VATS for you who have forgotten is a system that stops gameplay… I mean time and allows you to target enemy weak points and resume time with a touch of the button. This allows us to survive better but remember you have a limit to how much you can use it before it runs out.

Which is why you should buy our nuka-cola energy drinks for a special price of 5 caps!

Now proceeding near  the city of NPCs... I mean homeless people. You will see that while the conversations with them can be dynamic with many ways to approach them and handle a situation. They tend to not be that expressive. Don't mind that though its just them being shy.

Remember that how you develop yourself as a human being will change how you can approach these guys and other situations on your travels.

Don’t worry though if you collect a bobblehead I’m sure it could make up for your lack of intelligence or anything else!

Now put on your toxic suits thats under your seats we are heading into the toxic tunnel infested with ugly... i mean disfigured mutated humans. They are victims of the after-matches of the war and tend can be hostile towards you. Its important to note that you can choose to align yourself with one faction or another to win them over. Which tends not to be as complex as new vegas as a result of relying on equipment for doing this.

Don’t worry while we don’t have casinos that are grand like New Vegas every day is a huge gamble to live or die so remember you can skip hours of a day if need be by sleeping.

Up next is the ship of dreams
date:
where scientists come together to figure out the future. Rumors have it that the main reason to come here is the research on clean water systems. The scientists are trying to find to make the water clear and drinkable for all.

The incoming tour of an alien spaceship is brought to you by Unknown Inc. Where even the employees don't know each other. The DLC… I mean discoveries located casually during this tour.. are well worth your wait and price of admission. We have discovered that the environments are completely different and well thought out layouts are quite nice especially seeing new friendly face…

Remember folks how you develop yourself as a human being is what this game.. I mean place is about and I highly recommend paying to move into one of these broke down… I mean luxurious homes.

reviewText:
What can one say about one of the greatest games ever made?
It's hard to put into words just how much I love the Fallout franchise and how much I adore this game. Bethesda have done a wonderful job with Fallout 3, bringing Adamowicz's amazing illustrations to life, sparing no detail.
There are hundreds of NPC's who either want to talk to you or put your head on a platter, not to mention there are countless missions and some random encounters that will stay with you for the rest of your life.
The Capital Wasteland can be a dark and depressing place; yet it's the little settlements and unique characters you come across on your travels, that make everything you work toward worthwhile.

reviewText: An unbelievable well made game, one of the best games ever made. The graphics, gameplay, plot, lore, music score, and art style are just astounding. Without dlc, this game is awesome. Other games in the top 10 that I recommend(PC or Console): Mass Effect 2, BioShock, Legend of Zelda(Majora's Mask, Ocarina of Time, etc.), Civilization 5, Mario 64, Portal 2, Half-Life 2, Super Smash Bros Melee, Last of Us. reviewText:
This game is a classic and, as I have already played the game when it was released with a physical disc copy, it would get a thumbs up from me under normal circumstances...

BUT

The steam version, in it's current condition and if you're unlucky does not work as it should. There are crashes for just about every operation the game performs. If you google Fallout 3 crashes you will be treated to a cornucopia of nine or more fixes for reasons the game could crash. Do you have a processor with more than one core? Crash. Do you have a laptop with an integrated graphics card? Crash. Do you have autosave on? Crash. Do you have Windows newer than Vista? Crash. Did you forget to sacrifice to Cthulu before booting? Crash.

This may not apply to you though, it seems some of these instances are more serious than others. I myself got the lucky draw of several of these risks, playing on a laptop running Win7 with an integrated graphics card and a quad core CPU.
The only reason I didn't return the game after rebuying it digitally was that I got it to work somewhat after doing a convoluted set of tasks that may or may not have involved cthulu in some form of desperate plea for help.

So after modding the game with a file that overrides the graphics options, fiddling with settings in both the launcher and ingame, setting compatability for WinXP and having to order the laptop to only use one cpu in task manager every time I load the game  (Because OF COURSE it resets every time you reboot the game) I got it to work, allthough it eventually crashed again and this time, having saved up it's spite for a good hour, it crashed so hard it froze my entire computer and I had to do a hard reset to make it work properly again.

I do hope that I am wrong though, and that this was a case of the integrated graphics cards gremlins, which presents a much less all-engrossing scope. Fallout 3 is a legend in it's own right, a classic that everyone and anyone should be able to try out or re-visit.

reviewText:
Very good game,despite it's age

Fallout 3 is a very good post-apocalyptic action RPG game with a big open-world map filled with many locations to explore(221 with the DLCs,and 163 only in vanilla),a pretty interesting story which consists of 14 main quests,17 side quests,and another 38 unmarked quests(I recommend you doing the side quests because they're not related to the main ones and are very interesting).The game's time lenght is ~14 hours only for the main story and 100+ if you want to complete every quest in the game,the DLCs,and to explore every location.
The game occasionally crashes on Windows 7,8,10 but you can reduce the chance by following  this guide .
Below are the Pros and Cons of the game.

Pros
------------------------     Big world with lots to do
Very good post-apocalyptic atmosphere
Fun combat (both FPS and VATS)
Many weapons to choose from
Many perks and skills to level up (58 perks,79 with the ones from DLCs.And 13 skills)
Highly moddable
Each DLC takes place in a separate and unique map
Cons
------------------------     Main story is kinda short
Has fewer choices compared to other games in the series
No iron sights (you can add them with mods)
Occasionally crashes on Windows 7 and above (check the link above)
Still has bugs (nothing game-breaking)
Also,mini-reviews for the DLCs:

Mothership Zeta I personally didn't like this one.It's way too linear,basically it was just running around,pressing buttons and killing aliens.The story was kinda boring and it doesn't even have side quests.But the ending is cool though.It's like 3 hours long.

Point Lookout My personal favourite.It's a very good DLC with a beautiful setting and good story.It's open-world and has side-quests too.It's like 5-6 hours long if you do everything.

Broken Steel It basically continues the game's main story.It's pretty interesting,has side-quests and free-roam and it takes place in the vanilla world except the last mission.It takes like 5 hours to beat everything in it.And also raises the level cap to 30 when installed.

Operation: Anchorage It's a good linear DLC that takes place in a simulation.It's very short,like 2-3 hours.

The Pitt Beautiful setting(yeah,I like post-apocalyptic settings) and nice story.It's ~4 hours long.

Conclusion? It's well worth the full price and can't wait to play it again with different perks,builds,and quest choices.

Note: This is my first ever review, so I'm sorry if I forgot to mention some important or necessary details.

reviewText:
Lots of people would have a couple hundred more hours if Bethesda would fix & optimize the game to work with Windows 7 & 8.
Other than that tedious issue, it's an amazing game, especially with mods! Mods like GNR Enhanced, Point Lookout Reborn, Alton Il, Vault 101 Revisited, and more really spruce the game up.

There's lots to do in the wasteland, such as...
-Slavery! (Yes, really.)
-Destroy an entire town!
-Kill a mugger!
-Shoot things!
-Use V.A.T.S.!
-Give water to people!
-Explore!
-Save/Reloading!
-Modding!
-Kill aliens! (Mothership Zeta)
-Loot!
-Steal things!
-Be evil!
-Be good!

There's lots more to do, but let me get to the gameplay.

It's an RPG, FPS, game. You are also given V.A.T.S., which lets you take a moment, and plan your shots out. You can cripple an enemy's legs, then deal with them, shotgun style, or just shoot their head, like everyone does.
You can talk to many residents of the Wasteland. Some will be your companion, others will give you quests, and some prefer shooting first.
Fallout 3 has quests. Main storyline quests, sidequests, and unmarked quests. Storyline and sidequests show up in your Pip-Boy 3000 under the Quests tab, while unmarked quests don't. Things like supplying people with Sugar Bombs (food), or Scrap Metal are unmarked quests.


If you're a fan of shooters, and RPG's, this is a game for you.

reviewText:
I guess I should write a review about the best RPG game I have ever played. Don't let my hours played fool you, I have played through the entire story and all DLC's on my playstation 3 a lot of times and still I haven't seen everything (EDIT: I am also playing with mods currently so all the time I have played in the last month and everything I will play won't be counted (as of 19-3-2016)).

Which brings me to my first 'Pro'

Pros:

-A HUGE amount of content, it is insane how much there is to do in Fallout 3. The map is big, there are a lot of places to discover, people to talk to, quests to do, items to find, computers to hack, locks to pick and enemies to shoot. A vast assortment of mods add a lot to this already amazing game!

-The story is good, its nothing special but it is good enough, the DLC's are also amazing and have their own stories!

-DLC done right, this isn't some cash grab DLC game, the DLC's add new items, enemies, lore and more to the game!

-Great atmosphere, the music is really good too!

-Your choices matter, the dialogue system is great, although the characters you talk to are a bit 'lifeless'.

Cons:

-Stiff NPC's/unrealistic animations, When you talk to someone they stand still like they are a tree, the animations aren't very good either.

-Graphics are very outdated, this isn't a con to me personnaly but it might throw some people off, ofcourse there are mods to make it look better!

-Bugs and glitches, sometimes funny, sometimes game breaking.

I recommend this game because I think it is amazing, video games are truly a form of art.

Steel be with you!

reviewText:
Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition is a first-person open world post-apocalyptic RPG. After escaping from Vault 101, a subterranean nuclear fallout shelter you lived in all your life, you explore the post-nuclear war-torn wastelands of Washington DC while on the trace of your father's footsteps.

Pros: 1st person perspective is a huge departure from the original Fallout games that add to the immersiveness. The game offers a very large world to explore, filled with bandits, super mutants, ghouls and radioactive creatures. I love the bottle caps as currency, although you're likely to mostly barter for ammos and equipment in exchange for the incredible amount of scraps and junk you can scavenge. There's a nice amount of guns to get your hands on, drugs (or chems) to give you boosts, and an assortment of food and medicine to keep your health up, most of which is irradiated which forces you to carefully manage your radiation poisoning. Quests are plentiful, and everywhere you go you'll have people asking for help in these hard times. The RPG elements consists of your basic attributes and trained skills, while leveling up allows you to train those skills and assign perk points to an increasing list of perk options, so that you may make your character just the way you want it. The VATS system allows you do precision targeting in fights, with VATS points just limited enough to avoid over use.

Cons: The world design is not on par with modern post-apocalyptic setting: wastelands feel barren and empty, buildings look and feel repetitive, and the urban DC area is nothing but impassable walls of concrete rubble with only the occasional building you can actually get in. Graphics and character designs feel repetitive and didn't age well. Gameplay does include a third-person option, but it's basically the same as the first-person option except that you see your character's back. Getting started can discourage newcomers as the early game is much harder and players spend most of their time going back and forth carrying junk with their limited carrying capacity to barter for barely as much ammos as they spent getting their loot, assuming the few vendors even have any stock of ammos compatible with the guns you have.

Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you

I'm threading lightly as not everyone will enjoy this game: it's not as lively as Fallout 4, not as deep as the Metro series, and doesn't have the personality of the Borderland series. If you're a classic Fallout fan looking for a modern take on the isometric cRPG style, you should probably be looking at Wasteland 2. Otherwise, this game and its DLCs will give you dozens upon dozens of hours of gameplay, so of course I recommend it!

P.S.: Those experiencing compatibility issues can fix this through the use of Mods. Unfortunately, these are not supported by Steam and installing an external 3rd party Mod manager will prevent this game from running normally through Steam. If Star Wars: Knight of the Old Republic II can have Steam Workshop support added a decade after release, I see no reason or excuse for Bethesda not to do the same with their original take on the Fallout franchise.
—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

reviewText: Although New Vegas is much more popular, and has more to do, I prefer Fallout 3's story. Because you see yourself born you become more emotionally invested in the story then you would with the Courier. The only downside is that the main campaign has pacing issues and doesn't let you know when the final mission is so odds are you'll finish it before you wanted to.\n\nThe DLC actually breaks the game though, so I'd advise playing through it once and then deactivating it after the playthrough. The DLC added monsters are more or less boss level and are spawned in mixed with regular enemies in most cases.

reviewText:
Fallout is love. Fallout is life.

If you're like me and never played previous fallout games then you will be a bit confused when you play the game for the first time. But after about an hour into the game you simply can't stop playing.
Okay so here is my story: i started playing this game right before Fallout 4 came out since i was too poor to afford FO4 at that moment so i watched a few reviews on YouTube and decided to play it. As i said if you're new to the franchise like me, you will be confuse about how some elements in the game work right off the bat but that dissapears shortly after 1h into the game.

You are born and raised into a vault untill the age of 19 i think because of a nuclear blast and after some incidents you are bound to get the ♥♥♥♥ out of the vault. After that the fun begins. It's YOU vs THE WASTELAND.
The fallout 3 world is so god damn massive that even with my 10 hours of gameplay i haven't come close to completing even 10% of the game. There is a main story and many many side quests that you can choose to do. They are all equally fun so i suggest doing them all, well, you don't really have a choise to be honest. you will be so addicted to the game that it will be hard for you NOT to go for all quests.

You can choose how you want to play the game and every action you do effects the ending of the plot. There are many endings so prepare yourself to be either as good as possible or as evil as possible.

10/10 would recommend

reviewText:
Have you ever been a long-time fan of something, gotten really excited when you heard it was coming back, only to be massively disappointed with the result? Fallout 3 had this effect on many fans of the Fallout series, myself included. When developing Fallout 3, Bethesda only kept what was valuable to Fallout. Not “valuable” to the series and what made it so great, but valuable in terms of measurable monetary value. Fallout 3 is an attempt at bringing Fallout to the “modern gamer” and it’s one of the few things Bethesda did right.

Right from leaving the Vault you can see that the game is very good looking with a nice aesthetic style, too bad it’s ruined by that horrendous green tint. Despite being pleasing to look at the game world is very badly designed. Locations are randomly placed and most of them bear little or no significance at all. On top of that, there is almost no variation in the caves, buildings or those damned metro tunnels. Once you been through one, you’ve been through them all. And to make matters even worse, exploration in the game in more chore than challenge as enemy levels are scaled with the player, meaning as long as you’re decently equipped and not caught off guard, you’ll breeze right through anything.

Gameplay is familiar; it plays as if it’s “The Elder Scrolls IV.5: Fallout”. Bows replaced by guns, skills reworked, etc. On the surface it’s not really a bad thing, combat is more complex than TES but (much) less so than previous Fallouts. Your weapon skill determines your accuracy and damage dealt (this also applies to guns, even though that’s not how guns work) and your number of Hit Points is derived by your Endurance. Skills have been reworked so that “Tagging” a skill only increased its base by 15 points, no longer increasing the rate the skill increases during point distribution on level ups. Also, perks are now gained upon every level up as opposed to every third. Meaning by the time you reach the default cap of level 20, you’ll be nigh unstoppable. Attributes (Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck) have been almost completely trivialized, doing little outside of increasing the base number for your skills. And the availability of the perk “Intense Training” only further trivialises the allocation of attribute points. Unfortunately even 5 years post release, the game is still full of potentially game breaking bugs, even after being blatantly dumbed down for the 360 and PS3. And the PC version isn’t much better either, unless you’re running Window Vista then get used to reading “fallout3.exe has stopped working” every hour or so.

The original Fallout sent you on a quest to find a replacement controller chip for your vault’s water purifier and Fallout 2 had you finding a Garden of Eden Creation kit to save your tribal village from a severe drought. Both are for the benefit of many, where Fallout 3’s main quest is personal. Leave the vault and find your father. Having a personal goal in a Fallout game was a strange choice. In the first two games you end up having a great impact on the rest of the wasteland, eradicating the Super Mutant threat or the Enclave in Fallout and Fallout 2 respectively. Fallout 3 main quest ends up being a lazy compilation of all these objectives from the previous games and seems pointless. Why are we competing against the Enclave when A: The Enclave was destroyed in Fallout 2 and B: They want the exact same thing we want. So why not team up? It’s certainly not for control of the area, because people seem to be doing fine without a source of pure water. The illusion of player choice exists but you have almost no influence on the story or game world with your decisions. The Evil path doesn’t seem like it is there for players who want to commit to being evil, but there for players who just want to murder people for the fun of it. An example of this wasted potential is in an early side quest, where you can either blow up a town for two obnoxiously stupid characters for reasons which are cryptically arbitrary, or you can save the down by defusing the bomb the town is for some reason based around. Blowing up the town nets you destroying one of the game’s main hubs for nothing more than a cool looking explosion.

You’ll find through your travels that there is a strangely limited number of NPCs/town in most of cases, a couple generic citizens with a handful of named characters. How the player can interact with the NPCs is even more limited. Dialogue has been seriously dumbed down since Fallout 2, both in terms of writing quality and sheer number of choices of what to say. Speaking of writing quality, you can’t expect me to believe that “You can’t be President. You’re an abortion of science. You need to die…” (one of the game’s skill check dialogue options) is something that a scientific mind would say, can you Emil Pagliarulo? The delivery of dialogue is just as bad. The number of voice actors is extremely small all sound uninspired, even celebrity Liam Nesson’s performance is off on a few of his lines. Bad writing, bad delivery along with bad facial animation makes NPC interaction nothing to look forward to, at least most of them have very little to say.

It’s obvious that Bethesda aren’t familiar with the Fallout universe as there are many inconsistencies to be found in Fallout 3, both with lore and its own story. Most obvious is the changes to the Brotherhood of Steel. Because of Bethesda’s apparent inability to creatively and skilfully write opposing factions with unique and believable motives, they wrote the Brotherhood of Steel to be the goody-two-shoes of the game, as opposed to them being the xenophobic tech-nuts they once were. This is explained in-game as the Elder of the BoS chapter exploring the east suddenly deciding to abandon the Brotherhood’s primary goal of recovering advanced technology to do nothing but help old ladies across the street. This “explanation” was clearly an afterthought used so that the BoS could be in the game for brand recognition. The Garden of Eden Creation Kit was just a mere collection of seeds and horticulture tips in Fallout 2, but in Fallout 3 it’s completely rewritten as some kind of magical life-bringing device to save the wastes from radiation for no reason other than it suited Bethesda’s writing. It seems that rather tell their story in the Fallout world Bethesda shaped the Fallout world around their story, which makes very little sense in of itself.

The game’s atmosphere is good as a standalone, but as a Fallout title it’s completely off. Bethesda did a great job of capturing the mood of Fallout but not its atmosphere. All this assuming you’ve turned the OST off of course. For some reason Bethesda chose to abandon the atmospheric music of the first two games in favour of the action movie soundtrack that assaults your ears. Which gives player the only difficult choice of the game: Do I listen to this travesty of an OST? Or do I listen to THREEEEEEEEEE DAAAAAAAAWWWG, the most out of place character in the game.

If you’re looking for a fun shoot and loot game with lots to explore then this is the game for you. If you’re looking for an RPG experience with complex characters and depth in the gameplay then you’re better off looking elsewhere. It succeeded as a way of bringing a loved series to a new generation of gamers, but it alienated lots of fans of the original games.

reviewText:
10/10
All in all a brilliant game. Buy it if you like any sort of open world games, buy it if you like game that have an emphasis on character freedom, buy it if you love the idea of running around the wasteland shooting mutant zombies with laser pistols while 50's swing is playing through your arm radio.

Pros:
Brilliant atmosphere
Great setting
Massive world
Good questing
Nice mix of retro sci-fi and post apocalyptia
Fantasic soundtrack
Deep dialogue
Cheap, especially at sales
Great array of available mods
A gun that shoots nukes
Swag DJ
Your dad is Liam Neeson

Cons
Unstable on Win 7 (easily fixed with some interweb searching)
Outdated graphics (by no means bad graphics, just a little old)
Certain modern mechanics are lacking (no aim down sights or grenade button and things like that)(NOTE: you can get most of these features through mods)
Fiddley menus

NOTE: I only have a small number of hours cause I have modded it and run it through Fallout Mod Manager as a non-steam game.

reviewText:
Broke game in two minutes by closing the gate on the playpen before dad could get out trapping him forever. 10/10
I have only eleven minutes logged on steam. However I played this extensively up until the release of NV and beyond then too on my 360. I use FSE so the time doesn't get logged on steam as it removes the overlay. So my total playtime is over 1000 hours I expect. This is a post-apocalyptic masterpiece. I played it for countless hours discovering every solitary bobblehead, nuka cola quantum and all 5 behemoths. I bought the DLC on release out of a desire for more of this post apocalyptic adventure.

*spoilers*

I left the vault in search of a father who left me feeling betrayed. I found him only to have him taken again so soon. I killed Colonel Autumn as vengeance for my father. I came back from the dead to continue my fathers dream and the war against the Enclave, I became a member of the Lyons Pride and the Brotherhood of Steel to cram a power armoured fist down their throats in an effort to rid their evil from the capital wasteland. Then I settled down in my Megaton home, and life was good.

*spoilers over*

Then I started all over again. This time as a knife weilding pyromaniac, then again, as a tech expert with a knack for explosives and lasers. I kept playing this game over and over, because while the story wasn't NYT bestseller material, it engaged me. The world was interesting with interesting people such as a benign super mutant and old lady hoping for a violin and a man seeking freedom for his band of former slaves and the smart mouthed little p12!ck who lead a town of children. The game looked good to me with its blasted landscapes and shiny monochrome vaults and misplaced tower rising in the south, broken D.C landmarks and its mushroom clouds which conjured a sense of horror as you realise just how much devestation the power of the atom can bring. This game is one of my all time favourites. Sure it has bugs and glitches. Sure the graphics and gameplay are dated but this is still a damn good game. A lot of the old time FO 1&2 diehards hated this. And that is ok. Because sometimes the old games just feel right and this dramatic a change can turn some off. I never played the originals. I tried, but they are too dated for me and I wish I could get into them, but hey.

If, somehow, you don't own this game. I beseech you, get it now and know the cell mutating joy that I did the first time I explored the capital wasteland and became the lone wanderer.

reviewText:
Short version: 82%Is it The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion with firearms and a burnt-out wasteland? Yes, it is, with all of the good and all of the bad. The good being a masterfully crafted world that is a joy to explore again and again, with enjoyable combat, loads and loads of items, and an atmosphere that will never let you go. And the bad being the paper thin plot line and almost amusingly bad dialogues, complemented by equally atrocious voice-acting. So, in essence, it’s your usual Bethesda game: a great dungeon crawler with a bad story.

Long version:When the first previews were seen about Fallout 3, everybody thought that the new owner, Bethesda just re-skinned their high-selling game, Oblivion, slapped in some firearms, and called it a day. In some manner it’s true, Fallout 3 is not like any other previous Fallout titles, which included two turn-based isometric RPGs, a TBS/RPG hybrid, and a top-down button-mashing hack-and-slash. Fallout 3 on the other hand is an action-RPG/FPS hybrid dungeon-crawler, which features all the trademarks of the Elder Scrolls series, including the good and the bad.

The Good: The game world is jaw-dropping. The ruins of Washington D. C. are a marvel to look at, and the surrounding wasteland offers plenty of smaller and larger places and secrets to discover. The map is enjoyable enough to start a new character for the sole reason of exploring it again.
The combat is heavily biased in the player’s favour, but it’s still fun. It’s also very violent and gory. Although it features less death animation than the old 2D games, they are so brutal it’s almost a guilty pleasure to wander around and blow the super mutants and the raiders to tiny, bloody bits.

The Bad: Practically everything that involved the writing staff. The main plotline is just a mishmash of Fallout 1 and 2 with little cohesion and a plethora of plot holes. The established lore is either misused with little understanding, or simply contradicted (again, Elder Scrolls players are probably used to this). The dialogues and the voice acting ranges from somewhat tolerable to downright painful.
Also, like in the case of all GameBryo engine (and Fallout) titles, it’s essential to install the community-created patches to get rid of the thousands of bugs and game-breaking glitches, including one where it’s impossible to start the game on Windows 7 or later. (Visit the community for a guide on how to do this.)

Overall, Fallout 3 is an immensely enjoyable dungeon crawler. Just forget the storyline and that it’s supposed to be set in the same world as the much-loved originals, and enjoy the hundreds of hours of exploration and mutant hunting!

reviewText:
Disclaimer: Long, and a side quest spoiler. TL; DR This game takes awhile to get exciting, but its well worth it.

Rather than discuss why I recommend this game, allow me to post a slight side quest spoiler, as it really captures the moment where I fell in love with Fallout 3.

As I was exploring the wastes, I came across a sizeable tower. As I neared this tower, I saw a Ghoul (ie looks like a Zombie but is  in full control of his body/mind) aruging with someone over an intercom. Naturally I eavesdropped and discoverd the Ghoul wanted to bring his people into the tower, and the people in the tower, very clearly did not want them in.

So as the dismissed Ghoul left I naturally tried my hand at getting into the tower. As I was a human, they let me in no problem. Its there that I picked up a quest to eliminate the Ghouls, as they were become increasingly bothersome to the residents. So I ventured into the tunnels, and found the leader whom I saw previously yelling into the towers intercom. He proposed a different solution, one that would let him and his band of ghouls forcefully take over the tower.

I weighed my options. Most tower citizens were not bigots, so I saw no reason to kill them to let the Ghouls in, yet I did not want to elimite the Ghouls. Not agreeing with eliminating either party, I opted for a more peaceful route.

After a few speech persuasions, (maybe a few stealthy murders) I persuaded the majority of the citizens in the tower to let the Ghouls in. The ghouls moved in shortly after. All was well. I had done it. I had solved a problem, with both parties intact.

or so I thought.

I returned to check up on my Ghoul/tower residents, and I noticed something amiss. The former tower leader, was gone, and so were a few of the other human residents. Some investigating later, I found the bodies of a few of the previous Human occupants, shoved in a storage closet. I questioned the Ghoul leader, and he dismissed the murders as accidents" related to "disagreements".

I lost it. I slayed every single Ghoul in that tower
date: I felt betrayed. Had I not done the good thing? I made two groups coexist. In my quest for an ideal solution I did not see the underlying problem.\n\nAnd now my charecter sits in an empty tower. Filled with neither Ghouls nor Humans
recommended: contemplating the error of my choice
hoursPlayed: dwelling on my unsastisfying rampage against the ghouls that betrayed me. All the while marvelling at the game design
voteText: and how it made clear moral choices murky."

reviewText: To start off, this game is great. I have had tons of fun playing it and it runs flawlessly without any problems on both of my Windows 7 computers. If you are a fan of post-apocalyptic game settings where you travel across a wastland shooting whatever you come across or sneaking past an enemy if you don't want a conflict, then this game is one you should consider buying. With that said, this game does have problems running on some windows 7 and 8 computers. I have had friends who have spent hours trying to get it to run on their computers, some have been successful and others have not. I just happened to be lucky enough to have a computer able to run it without changing anything.
