reviewText:
I have over five thousand hours in this game. I have it for Games for Windows LIVE and XBOX 360, now I have my 3rd copy, Steam. I have completely finished the game and every aspect it has to offer time and time again, creating countless mods with the GECK. How did I do this, you may ask? Well, I've played it ever since its US release in 2008 and played nearly every day on my old Windows XP and more recently my Windows 7. The way you get it to work on your Windows 7 is you go to your Documents > My Games > Fallout3 > FALLOUT.INI. In lines 88-89, change bUseThreadedAI to 1 and add iNumHWThreads=2 just after it. This makes the game use Threaded AI and it makes the game use only 2 CPU cores; otherwise the game will continuously crash. After you do this, the game will be more stable than Fallout New Vegas.

Alright. Onto the review.

Setting
The game is set in a post-apocalyptic, retro-futuristic Washington, D.C. following the Great War between the U.S., China, the Soviet Union and other countries. The Great War occurred on October 23, 2077 which caused immense damage and destruction despite lasting less than two hours. Before the Great War, there were the Resource Wars that nearly crippled the world and brought riots to the streets, during which the United Nations disbanded, and a Forced Evolutionary Virus plague coupled with global terrorism rendered the United States paranoid of both real and imagined communist plots. Canada was annexed by the United States in order to help the U.S. war effort against the Chinese in Alaska. The fact that Canada had the plentiful resources of nearly untouched wilderness made America's effort well worth the protection the U.S.A. promised to provide.

The World
Rust, decay, and creeping vegetation infest monuments from before the Great War. Amidst the ruins of Washington, D.C., the Capitol, the Jefferson Memorial and the battered remains of the Washington Monument still stand in the desolate area that is now known as the Capital Wasteland. The central hub of civilization in the ruins of the former capital is Rivet City, based in the remains of an aircraft carrier carried far inland and beached by a catastrophic tsunami whose waters have long since receded. Other settlements include the towns of Megaton, Arefu, Tenpenny Tower and Paradise Falls. Movement through the downtown area and settlements is possible through the Washington Metro tunnels and crossing the desolate nuclear wasteland.
The Brotherhood of Steel community is stationed in the Citadel, built in the ruins of the pre-War Pentagon where they attempt to preserve as much pre-war technology as possible. Super mutants, who since emerging from their refuges, have waged an unceasing war against what remains of humanity, trying to invade their territory and capture them. The Enclave - the self-styled inheritors of the power of the United States government - under the leadership of their new President John Henry Eden and his ruthless second-in-command Colonel Augustus Autumn, are the player's biggest foes in the game.

Emotional Impact
At the very beginning of the game we are introduced to the Player's father, voiced by Liam Neeson. Character development is thown at us in the first few seconds of the game, great start. I shouldn't already be bored within the first 10 minutes of a game. Fallout 3 does very well to keep it that way.
The one (but not only) thing Fallout 3 does fantastic is character development.

There'd be more to this review but I would be spoiling it; if you haven't already done so, BUY THIS GAME!!! WORTH EVERY PENNY! Take it from me, I have 3 copies of this game!

reviewText:
For the most part, Fallout 3 lives up to the hype.  I had a great deal of fun with this game for the first thirty hours of play or so.  The RPG character development is strong, the FPS aspect is great considering it's an RPG, and the VATS system which is a combination of both is unique and adds a certain cinematic appeal to combat.  And of course, the perk system adds a certain excitement to leveling up that wasn't standardized for RPG gaming yet at the point of this game's release.

The open world is exciting to explore as you seem to run across all kinds of events and quests that (as far as I could tell) you weren't handheld and led to from any other place in the game.  The main storyline and the enjoyable DLCs lead you to the far corners of the map, though additional quests are plentiful.  Multiple quests also seem to offer something entirely unique, especially those related to the DLC, where you'll unlock special perks and otherwise unobtainable weaponry - weaponry which often has its own mechanics that differentiate it from other gear in the game.

My only complaint with the game, and this may be self-inflicted, is that as I neared the end and started playing the different DLCs it seemed to begin to drag.  I ended up having to push myself to start the game up, even though I, generally, enjoyed my time playing the game even then.  This could be related to your character becoming drastically overpowered if you allow them to in the higher levels.

All in all, a great game and one that I highly recommend to RPG and Post-Apocalyptic fans.  I secondarily recommend this game to FPS, as the gunplay is fun, but it won't blow your mind if that's solely what you're hopping into the game for.

reviewText: Fallout 3 delivers on almost everything you can do to attest for a perfect game. The first fully 3d game in this series breaks off its original roots but for the better. Filled with hundreds of hours of lore, quests, secret items and  post apocalyptic locations you will be pulled in from the start. Create your own character and take to the harsh wasteland to make your own legacy. The combat its self can be clunky at times but never takes away from the experience. SOund in this game is damn near perfect from every footstep to the old fashioned music on the radio. Ever wonder what a post apocalyptic 50,s setting would be like? Then step right on up you are home now.\n\nFinal Score: 10/10

reviewText:
Great game, revives the original Fallout series and brings it to the new era. Deep characters, strong story and magnificent post-apocalyptic feeling in one of the best games of the '00s.

As in all Bethesda games, player skill matters in FP view but the RPG mechanics are there and are very important, much more than in other offerings of the company.

Also a great mod community to keep you occupied for a long long time, after you're donw with the base game and the 5 DLCs included in this GOTY edition.

Must have for any serious gamer.

reviewText:
Alrighty, I'll try to make this short.
First of all, the game does work on Windows 7, (at least for me it does). The game is known to freeze and such, but there is an easy fix for it, it takes like not even 2 minutes lol. I looked it up on YouTube. Theres a couple really helpful videos I came across. (perhaps not everybody has the same issue so I don't know if the fix for the game freezing is the one and only problem, but that's all it was for me).

Second, the game isn't recording my hours for whatever stupid reason, but I have actually invested about 60 hours into the game now. I've completed some of the DLC's, reached level 23, haven't touched the main story much because I've been running around exploring the map. I've lost so much sleep playing this game lol. Simply put, for those of you who love The Elder Scrolls: Skyrim, Oblivion, or Morrowind, and want a game that is basically the same exact thing except set in a modern timeline, in an apocalyptic, gritty world (America) with guns.... and absolute freedom to do whatever, this is a game for you. It's 20 bucks, I'd say that's a steal for a game like this, and even better if you catch it on sale.

EDIT:
[Okay so the game does crash every 2 or 3 hours of playing, which isn't a big deal, but it's still annoying........ Fallout 3 launcher has stopped working"] :D"

reviewText: Fallout 3, surprisingly, is a game that was actually developed and made by Bethesda, and not a fan made mod. This is surprising because from just playing it, it can be hard to tell at times. I know I'm late to writing this review, but I wanted to remind both myself and anyone who reads this of how Fallout 3 was in case Fallout 4 doesn't seem as good as it looks when it comes out. (It may not look like it with the 90 minutes I have tracked, but I have completed the game twice; once from a retail copy and more recently through New Vegas using the Tale of Two Wastelands mod.)\n\nFallout 3 is set in the Capital Wasteland, a new location set on the opposite side of the US from the traditional west coasts of Fallout 1, 2, and later New Vegas. By doing this, they allowed themselves to have a clean slate of sorts, and have more creative freedom in writing the story. So naturally, being skilled writers as they are, they just copied a bunch of stuff from the old games and rewrote it to be worse. The Brotherhood of Steel is back, only this time they're a splinter faction that's a bunch of goodie two-shoes that go from shunning you to thanking you for letting them bask in your presence over the course of one quest (the real" brotherhood is still technically there in the form of the Outcasts

hoursPlayed: since the only reason caps were used as currency in the west coast games is because they were backed by the Hub. The whole game just feels like they went through a picture book of Fallout and saw cool things and went "hey that looks cool
voteText: let's put it in our game too!" without really thinking that much about why they would actually be there.\n\nGameplay-wise

reviewText: There's no doubt about it that Fallout 3 is one of the greatest, if not THE greatest, RPG of all time. With unprecedented gameplay, Fallout 3, in a way, paved the road, and remains relevent today. In 2008, Bethesda released Fallout 3, and within two years, they released amazing addon content. Overall, I would buy the Game of the Year Edition over the vanilla copy any day of the week. You get so much more from an already amazing game, such as an even larger map, more quests, more guns, more choice making, and in general, more fun stuff to do. Get this game if you haven't already. You will not regret it, I can assure you that.

reviewText: A truly epic adventure--an absolute stellar collaboration of FPS and RPG experiences. The vast open landscape allows unhindered exploration. The game offers a wealth of NPC characters, each having their own distinct personalities opening or limiting choices based on how you interact with them. The story conversations go far beyond simple dialog, offering players deep and rich character development. There's even multiple paths/outcomes depending on the choices you make throughout the game. Multitudes of different monster types and weapons. While the story and side missions are enough to keep anyone busy for hours on end, the DLCs are well integrated and keep the game fresh for many more.

reviewText: Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition is my 200th game review, it is also the first in a trilogy of Fallout games released since 2005, which are a continuation of the original Fallout series for the PC. Fallout 3 takes us to Vault 101, where you play as a male/female character of your choice who leaves the vault to search for their father. Along the way you encounter struggling towns, various NPC's, complete quests, explore, and dungeon delve buildings, ruins, and other vaults as you progress through the story.\n\nFallout 3 is a First Person RPG where you interact with your environment and engage in FPS-style combat with enemies. It has an impressive list of voice actors and an immersive story that pulls you into the world of the Post-Apocalyptic Capital Wasteland, essentially the ruins of what was once Washington, DC. Fallout 3 was a blast to play on the PS3, as well as the PC and spawned 2 sequels which take place after the events of 3. If you enjoy post-apocalyptic games as well as FPS combat and RPG's, I recommend picking this game up and giving it a try. The Game of the year edition comes with all 5 DLC's included, so make sure you pick up this particular edition to get the full Fallout experience. Don't forget to tune into Galaxy News Radio, and everyone's favorite disk jockey, Three Dog, for some memorable dialogue and music.

reviewText:
Fallout 3 is one of the best examples of the FPS-RPG Hybrid genre, combining the sprawling depth of a traditional isometric RPG  with the reflex-rewarding immersion of an FPS.  Rather than dumbing down the game to fit the expectations of the fast-twitch FPS gamer, Fallout 3 keeps nearly all of the Fallout series' trademark complexity, nuanced plot, numerous areas to explore and seemingly endless sidequests.  All this adds up to a truly HUGE sandbox game that you can easily spend hundreds of hours on, never getting bored.

That is not to say that Fallout 3 is perfect.  Like most Bethesda titles, Fallout 3 has quite a few bugs, ranging from minor to serious.  Hardly surprising given the sheer scale of the thing, and percentage wise it's a very small portion of the game.  Of course, the bug problem itself leads me to mention one of the best things about Fallout 3: moddability.

Fallout 3 is one of the most moddable games ever released on PC, with mods not only supported but encouraged by the publisher.  While you can't get into the nitty gritty of the engine itself using the SDK (unlike most Source or early Unreal games), basically everything else is fair game for being modded.  This can range from the mundane to the fantastic, anything from increases in weapon damage to entirely new plots with numerous side-quests and fully voiced dialog.  Fallout 3 in itself is an amazing game, but with the appropriate mods - chosen from the literally thousands available - it can become truly awe-inspiring.

Mods can also include fixes to the bugs that Bethesda left in the game.  Yes, Bethesda may not have fixed all their mistakes in Fallout 3, but they at least left behind tools so that the fans can.

All that said, what you should take away from this review is that Fallout 3 is a really, really, really good game.  It takes very little time - as little as fifteen minutes - before the game has thoroughly sucked you in, and once you're hooked you can spend literally hundreds of hours playing and enjoying.  At time of writing I have more than 200 hours logged on the game and there are STILL areas in the Capital Wasteland I am encountering for the first time.  That's serious replayability.

reviewText:
Fallout 3, the game itself, is fantastic.

But do not buy it.

The installation is plagued with compatibility issues, necessitating you to go reading through third party guides just to find out how to properly install the game you paid for. Then, in game, there are other issues you have to constantly be aware of or else your game will crash. For example, did you know you cannot save over old save files? If you do, and load your game, it will freeze and crash every single time. There is no in game warning for this, just as there is no warning on the game page that this game is incompatible for most computers made after 2007 (as I've said, you have to read through third party guides and install third party mods just to play the vanilla version of the game).

I do not know how it's legal to sell a broken product with no official warning given to potential customers. They use weasel langauge and say that the game is not 'Optimized' for Windows 7 and beyond instead of outright saying it will not work, which is the issue. Hopefully some people decide to read the reviews about the game on Steam and realize just how much of a headache they'll be going through just to install and play the normal, unmodded version of the game. And don't forget - never, ever save over an old save file (a bug the programmers never warn you about nor one they give you option to disabled) or else you can say goodbye to hours of gameplay.

Fallout 3 - the game itself is great. Installation is a massive problem (for no reason, since it's still possible to install with third party mods not officially created or endorsed by Bethesda, the game creators), and there are too many game ruining bugs. Seeing as how it's been years since this game was released, these issues are obviously never going to be addressed by the company - I suppose it's just easier to slap an extremely vague warning (hidden in the middle of the sale page) and just keep letting unaware customers continue buying a game they don't support than it is to have some integrity and intiative and fix the game. If you must play this game, find circular means - Bethesda obviously does not care about their customers consuming experience.

Given their treatment of customers, I will not buy (nor recommend anyone else to buy) any other games from Bethesda, Fallout 4 included. They are still charging a hefty price for a broken game (giving no warning to customers about the broken software), which can only be played with software created by dedicated fans who receive a sum total of zero dollars for making Bethesda's product workable for them. What a despicable company.

reviewText:
Fallout 3 was born out of Interplay's sordid history. Black Isle had already created it's own version of Fallout 3 that was never sold. Instead Interplay sold off the rights of Fallout to Bethesda who made this version on Oblivion's engine.

As much as I rag on Fallout 3 I have to acknowledge that Bethesda really went above and beyond with how well they did their homework. Most of the subtle 1950's satire was replicated extremely well with this game. Adding to that they decided to set it in D.C. to have creative control which was an excellent idea in my opinion. It allowed for unique locations like Little Lamplight, the Dunwich building and the Oasis.

However where my complaints start mostly have to do with the plot and the gameplay. For starters the main quest is moralistic garbage, painting the protagonist with the broadest brush possible as either the savior of humanity or the antichrist. The gameplay was also very video-gamey. With enemies taking a full 10 bullets to the face and still not dying.

There are mods that fix most of my complaints besides the plot. Even still when New Vegas came out 2 years later I found it fixed all the problems I saw with F3. Regardless, Fallout 3 is still a very enjoyable experience. Just not a perfect one.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=11214131

reviewText:
One of my most favorite games. First of all lets get this out of the way. The game is old, and the graphics aren't the best. But Bethesda doesn't care about graphics in their games. They care about the world and the story, and how free you are. You walk around post nuclear Washington DC. Being the good guy, bad guy, dude who doesn't ♥♥♥♥ing care, or whatever you can come up with.  The game never ceases to remind you of how ♥♥♥♥ed everything is. And some of the most interesting quests in rpgs come from this game. There are very few repetitive quests, unless you find the game mechanics repetitive (talking, walking, shooting.)  Another elephant I want to get out of the way; there is no aim-down-sights or sprint, and the game is not very immersive (due to bugs mostly.) But thanks to being on the pc, you don't have to worry about most bugs (game breaking ones, ones that make you reload to the last save because you are stuck in space), due to mods! ADS, sprinting, and bug fixes out the ♥♥♥ (for modding tutorials, I suggest gopher on youtube.) Basically after playing this game again just using about 2 or 3 mods, I realized what a jewel fallout 3 is, it gets you attached to things very easily, but mostly things like Megaton, robots, that black lady who gives you stimpacks, Hobo McDirtFace, even ♥♥♥♥ like teddy bears (if you have hoarding problems this game doesn't help.) But one thing you don't get attached to is your dad. I mean the story is engrossing but you don't really see much of him. Liam Neeson voices him but he only has about 30 or so lines because the amount of times you see is slim. You look for your dad half the game and you would suggest Bethesda to do something with the talent they had.


All in all, great game, mods make it better.


I tried to make this review trying not to be a parrot, but some things I think are shared opinions.

reviewText:
Fallout 3 does many things right. The most important of its strengths in my opinion, however, is its ability to immerse the player in an atmosphere filled with choice, unique experiences, and a world worth exploring.

The Fallout franchise has always done these things right, but Fallout 3 brought a new atmosphere and a new set of mechanics to an already great model. These mechanics all work extremely well and make Fallout 3 a revolutionary game. The combination of the dialogue system, V.A.T.S., and the functionality of the Pip Boy make gameplay smooth yet still very refreshing. The primary narrative is strong and supports the immersion of the gameplay, while the entirety of the wasteland is filled with areas full of depth and story that is present in almost no other game.

Revisiting Fallout 3 has only confirmed the undeniable strengths and with each playthrough, the player will surely find new areas and characters worth exploring and experiencing. For these reasons, Fallout 3, along with its predecessors, stand alone in their own sect of games. Along with these strengths, Fallout 3 added a certain undefineable charm as it broke into the 3-dimensional realm. NPCs, the world, and the physics make playing the game a real joy and keep a smile on your face the entire time.

Fallout 3 is a must-own game and represents a special era in gaming in my personal opinion.

reviewText:
Fallout 3 as it stands is one of the best video games of all time and if you havent played it you are really missing out on a great title. As it stands this version of Fallout may cause some issues with your computer if you don't use mods or know how to mod due to the fact that it's not optimised for  Windows 7 or any newer version. If however you are able to get this to work there are many good parts to this game.

Pros

-Massive open world
-Great modability
-Interesting story
-Great leveling and perks system
-Almost infinite replay value as 2 characters are never alike
-Many easter eggs and secrets to find
-Great DLC (not needed to have fun)

However like many games there are a couple issues with the game itself

Cons

-Bugs (can be fixed to some extent with mods)
-Frequent crashes

Overall this game even with the bugs and crashes is a 9.6/10 and seriously worth playing. Just be wary if you try to buy this title for the PC due to the incompatibility.

reviewText:
Third canonical entry of the beloved classical RPG franchise Fallout. First one ever produced in a decade, if you discount the spin-off Brotherhood of Steel tactical RPG and the action game released on Playstation. Also the first title since Bethesda took over. This one generate quite a bit of controversy within the Fallout community, largely due to the fact it plays different than previous titles, as Bethesda decides to use the Elder Scrolls' engine based on GameBryo, which obviously is what they excel at.

Contrast to previous titles' isometric CRPG aspect, Fallout 3 is recommended by the developer to play in First Person perspective, even though a third person is present in the game. Some may mistake this game as an FPS on first glance, but rest assured this is still a pretty heavy CRPG, where character development, stats, skills and perks play the most important role in terms of gameplay, rather than the player's aiming skill.

Suffice to say, Beth created this Fallout title with love and homage to the original titles produced by Interplay, who sold the license and rights to them. This curiously gathered a lot of hate within the community towards them, even though in my opinion it was Interplay's fault to mismanage itself and go bankrupt. Other than the perspective, this game plays and feels like a true Fallout title, all the concepts and aesthetics were nicely adapted into the familiar Elder Scrolls-like gameplay, which personally is quite a happy mix due to my loyalty to that series.

Needless to say, the gameplay leans more toward Elder Scrolls titles rather than the old Fallout games in the 90's. Some may see as a problem, but I don't. Especially if you live in 2015, you can literally find spiritual successers to every classic RPGs: Wasteland 2 to Fallout (and of course the original Wasteland, which Fallout is loosely based on), Pillars of Eternity to Baldur's Gate, Torment: Tides of Numenera to Planescape, Divinity: Original Sin to Ultima, and a bunch of excellent tile-based dungeon crawlers to the classics like Eyes of the Beholder in early 90s. So you see, Fallout 3 being different than before isn't a problem for me personally, and it surely wasn't a problem for the original Fallout crew, of which a large proportion of developers work for Obsidian to strike a deal with Beth to work on a title truer to the original spirit of Fallout to based on Fallout 3's base game. See New Vegas.

One benefit of Beth's taking over that no one can deny is obviously the production value. Fallout 3 is a step up in almost every direction up from Oblivion, which FO3 is built upon. Some folks jokingly name the new Fallout as Oblivion with guns"
date: which indeed tells some truth. Gone is the old turn based tactical combat
recommended: in with the new hectic real-time action with pausible VATS system which allows you to plan and spend your action points. I wouldn't favor one system over the other
hoursPlayed: but FO3 does bring some fresh air to this aged franchise.\n\nWorldcrafting wise
voteText: Beth does what it does best. Exploration is rewarding as ever. This time around

reviewText:
I haven't played this much yet since I aquired it on Steam, but I bought it on disc when it was released and I purchased each individual DLC upon release as well. I don't remember exactly how many hours I spent playing this game back in 2008 and 2009, but it must have been close to 100 hours. As a huge Fallout fan since the first back in the mid 90s, this was just the ultimate awesome!

This is truly one of the few games that kept me glued to my screen for a half a day at a time or more. I remember one week-end when I got home from work on Friday evening and played pretty much through to Sunday evening non-stop (minus food and required hygene etc.), but not many games have been able to do this! It's so immersive, so atmospheric and you just want to keep going until the next level, the next upgrade, the next weird encounter.

The GOTY edition includes all the DLCs, so you can definitely no go wrong here. If you have never played Fallout 3 yet (or any of the other Fallouts -- an complete sacrilege if you ask me!!), then play. Seriously, leave your vault and play. This is pretty much an all-time-hall-of-fame game

reviewText:
Fallout 3 is a very good RPG, with a lot of action thrown in it, and a very good story. Set in a post-apocalyptic world after a nuclear war, you'll find yourself travelling through the Capital Wasteland, which used to be Washington and its surrounding areas. Even though the world is post-apocalyptic, it still has a quite distinctive 50s feeling to it, as history in the Fallout universe is different from ours.

The story starts out somewhat simple. You live in Vault 101 with your father, but after he leaves one day, you must escape the Vault, and search for him. However, it's not as easy as it sounds, as you'll end up in the middle of a conflict for control of the Capital Wasteland.

The GOTY edition, which I'm reviewing, includes all 5 DLCs released for Fallout 3; and I'd say it's worth it getting this version over the regular edition, as they add a lot of content. From the snowy landscape of Alaska in Operation: Anchorage, to the final frontier, space, in Mothership Zeta, they all offer new quests, locations, and items; as well as enemies. Broken Steel, in particular, picks up the story from where it ends, adding three new quests after the main story.

The setting, as I mentioned, is based around the area of Washington, and there's plenty of places to discover. Even though it's not a faithful recreation (and even if you've never been to Washington), you can recognize some of its famous landmarks, like the Washington Monument, or the Lincoln Memorial.

As far as gameplay goes, it's RPG elements are quite good. Like in almost every RPG, you earn experience points and level up; each time you do, you get to distribute several skill points into the different skills, and you also get to choose a perk, which grants you extra abilities. What makes Fallout's system special, however, is, well, its SPECIAL system, in which, at the moment of creating your character, you define his seven main attributes (Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck), which not only affect your skills, but also things like your maximum health or carrying capacity. As far as the combat goes, it's pretty much an action game, and can be played both in first and third person; however, your skills will affect how well you do in combat. Of course, being an RPG, it's not all about combat; you'll find yourself doing several quests, even outside the main storyline, helping people all around the Wasteland. There's also tons of dialogue, you can always find someone who might have some valuable information for you, or you can even avoid some combat situations simply through dialogue!

Well, in conclusion, I think this is a very good game, and I recommend it. It's a great experience, after all. I'd also add that you should check out Fallout: New Vegas as well; I haven't reviewed it yet, but it was the first Fallout game I've ever played, and it's as good as Fallout 3, if not better.

reviewText:
October 31, 2008. Finally, after more than 10 years I would be able to continue my adventures in my most beloved franchise ever 'Fallout' (I did not count Fallout Tactics, which I also loved).

I was sceptical at first, since this would be first Fallout game made by Bethesda. Like others, I did not just want a 'Oblivion with guns', also being on the East-Coast would feel differently, compared to the other games in the series.

Right from the start the hand of Bethesda was clearly visible. Starting the game as a baby/toddler/teenager was probably not what Black Isle would've done. Also the storytelling is a bit more childish and immature (like in Oblivion). The story was praised by many and even got an award for best story that year. In my opinion, the story(telling) is one of the worst parts about the game. If you have played Fallout 1 and 2, you will notice the story of Fallout 3 is simply Fallout 1 & 2's story put together. There are also weird locations/quests and multiple things that do not really add up to the Fallout lore.

Aside from the story, Bethesda still did manage to create a beautifully post-apocalyptic world and kept the Fallout feeling mostly throughout the game. Graphically, the game has aged but it's still well playable.

The thing I love most about Fallout 3 is just wandering around the Capital Wasteland and find new locations, items/weapons/armor and/or easter eggs. Often you will enounter various enemies and npc's which either want to help you or destroy you.

Gameplay is fun aswell. Killing enemies feels satisfying, there are tons of weapons for you play around with, quests to finish, secret locations.... there's just too much for me to write down. simply put, Fallout 3 will most likely enjoy you for hundreds of hours and is a must-have for every RPG-lover.

reviewText:
Although I'm a dear fan to the Fallout series, I cannot bring myself to recommend this game to ANYONE until they read what I'll say about the game. And if, but only if, you can read through all the faults of the game and still want it, then I would recommend it.

The story for Fallout3 is something that starts out interesting. You begin as a small child to explore the world and quickly progress through your life until your father decides to hop on out of your life. This will lead you to begin your search through the wasteland in hopes of finding your father and question why he left. Sadly this fresh new idea will leave you scratching your head by the end of the game wondering why over and over again. More than once you find yourself 'ambushed' and cutscened away unable to do anything. Othertimes you'll find yourself facing a decision where you cannot, CANNOT, choose the most reasonable option just because. Although the main story is full of these moments, I often found myself in side-quests almost slackjawed in awe at some of the situations the game placed me in. So while the main story is lackluster, there are some interesting side-quests within the game that can make up for the main story.
Combat. Oh lord, the combat for this game. You have literally two options to pick from either you A.) Shoot thousands of rounds at an enemy until they die or B.) Use VATS to instantly vaporize your opponent with no problems. And although many might argue with my description of the combat, clearly these people have never played melee runs or min-maxed their talent points properly to become completely broken. Overall it's combat falls flat just like the TES Bethesda games which require you to simply click your Mouse 1 button enough times. Sadly dialogue with other characters often falls flat and you'll find yourself in a stale world where I truly felt ALONE despite being around ten or so characters.
I really cannot say anything bad about the soundtrack, most of the game consisted of real world songs which were all fantastic for their time and fit in with the atmosphere that Fallout 3 has to offer.

Overall the game suffers from a poor story with terrible gameplay mechanics, where the side-quests and looting seem to be the only redeeming features of the game.

reviewText:
While I am not entirely sure about Windows 7 32bit and Windows Vista 32 bit, but I can tell you this game does run on Windows 7 64bit and Vista 64 bit.

1.  Go to the Documents\My Games\Fallout3" directlory in your user account.

2. Open the file "FALLOUT.INI" file using a text editor (preferably WordPad).

3.  On the Keyboard press Ctrl+F and look fo the line "bUseThreadedAI=0" (without quotes) and replace it with "bUseThreadedAI=1"

4.  ***IMMEDIATELY BELOW THE LINE IN STEP 3*** add the following WITHOUT quotes "iNumHWThreads=n" and REPLACE "n" with the number of cores your CPU has.

5.  Exit wordpad and save changes when prompted to.

6.  In your steam library
date: Right-click on Fallout 3 and browse the local files of the game.\n\n7.  Right click on "Fallout3.exe" and got to the "Compatibility" Tab and check "Run progream as an administrator"
hoursPlayed:
and "Run this program in compatibility mode" and select Which ever version of Windows XP your OS lets you select.

8.  Do the same thing you did in Step 7 to "FalloutLauncher.exe"

And there you have it :-)"

reviewText:
Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition is a 2008/09 post-apocalyptic role-playing game that takes place in desolate wasteland of Washington DC. You play as the Lone Wanderer, who travels on a journey to find your Father (voiced by Liam Neeson) in the wasteland. Leaving Vault 101 takes personal risks and responsibility. Would you do the same?

Fallout 3 starts in the year, 2277, 200 years after the Resource War (United States versus China in a fight for remaining sources on Earth) ended suddenly due to atomic weaponry inflicting against the United States and the rest of the world. Washington DC takes the most damage due to its strategic and political significance. The question remains: What was your Father’s intention to leave Vault 101? The main story is good though some people argued that the plot is decent. In my perspective, the plot is typical and good. It’s not the best or have a strong presentation, but it’s good overall. The real reason for playing Fallout 3 has to be exploration and doing major side quests. Exploring the unknown world of post-apocalyptic Washington DC feels so amazing and worrisome at the same time. These two emotions is what makes the game feel so great. The setting is unpredictable. You may find an abandoned settlement that has a mysterious past,  reading journal entries on what caused a location to fall apart, or some batsh*t crazy thing comes to you when you almost finish investigating an area.

The gameplay is primarily first-person or third-person shooter that place strong emphasis on your gameplay type. You can go guns blazing, get a companion and do some killing, conduct stealth and light skirmishes, or just explore alone in the Capital Wasteland. What makes Fallout 3’s gameplay a bit special is the V.A.T.S (Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System) where you “paused” the game while targeting an enemy’s legs, arms, equipped weapon, and the head. The feature is pretty nice and does help you in dire situations. However, it’s a bit unfortunate that V.A.T.S makes the game paused and not real-time. The stealth mechanic is a mixed bag. You can practically invest a lot of points towards the Stealth skill to make your stealth “level” to what suits you. If your Stealth skill is low then the enemy will “automatically” notice you even when the enemy is not facing you and you are crouch-walking towards an unsuspected enemy. What frustrates me the most was that there is no iron sight or aiming down your equipped weapon. Aiming is mostly useless and “hip-fire” the equipped weapon seems to be what’s best.

Is there criticisms for Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition? Fallout 3 is definitely not perfect. There are a lot of technical issues and bugs that Bethesda Games Studios neglected. Many PC users now have Windows 7, 8/8.1, and Windows 10 and a high majority will most likely have an major technical issue that can or cannot be fixed. The games does crash to desktop in modern PC architecture due to no support of multi-core processing (when the game came out, it was dual-core). The solution is there to fix it, but it does not fully bandage the problem. The NPCs look stale, but mods do help make it better. The most critical aspect of the game is the karma system. In a post-apocalyptic setting, any person would know that there’s no (or little) black-or-white scenarios. The karma system is a good concept, but heavily flawed since conducting bad “actions” like stealing or pickpocketing is treated like a horrid sin.

The review sounds critical but why does it gives a thumbs up? The answer is simple: It is fun. I remembered when I got the Fallout 3 Collector’s Edition back in October 2008 (where you get the concept art book, featurette DVD, the vault boy bobblehead, and a lunchbox (yes, an actual lunchbox). Fallout 3 crash to desktop so often that I’ve lost count. For some reason, I didn’t too angry about it (even though I should have). Fallout 3 was the first video game that I actually got so immersive to. The setting draws you in and exploration is so much fun. Fallout 3 is one of a very few games that gameplay matters over graphics and “minor” flaws. Does the sequels like Fallout: New Vegas and Fallout 4 improved over Fallout 3? Certainly. Fallout 3’s default price is at $19.99 (for Game of the Year Edition). I’ve strongly recommend (for those who haven’t play Fallout 3) to get it on a steep discount of -75% ($5 USD or regional equivalent) since the game faces technical issues on today’s PC systems. Fallout 3 is certainly not top-tier game (when looking at it today), but the game was a marvelous achievement for a first-person shooter to be in an open-world setting.

reviewText:
Christmas 2008 - little 11 year old Skippy1300 (me :D) comes running to the christmas tree..

Opens first gift and  its a lunchbox (ohh yesss!).

You see, little Skippy had never played a fallout game or any elder scrolls games. He only wanted Fallout 3 from the hype he saw online.

Little did Skippy know that from there on, his life would be changed...

7 years later, Skippy1300 (still me :D) has grown into a diehard Bethesda fan. Spending countless hours in fl3 oblivion skyrim flnv (even though its not bethesda)

July 24th 2015 - Skippy is currently riding the fallout 4 hype train. He is revisiting his old friend fallout 3, while ignoring stupid distractions like his job, his family, and girlfriend... 11.10.15 isn't approaching fast enough :3

reviewText:
I first played Fallout 3 in 2010, on an xbox 360, I was blown away and an obsession was born in me.
The games story compared to New Vegas, isn't the best, but still amazing, I loved every second of it.
I played for 100+ hours and then a friend gave me his GOTY with all the DLC, I thought I was going to die. The DLC easily adds 100's of hours to the game, simply because Broken Steel, allows you to continue after the end of the base game.
The sidequests, and backstories, for everything are wonderfully done. And the in-game radio stations are just great, playing all the songs that just complete the atmosphere of the game.
Other than a few compatibility issues I ran into since I'm running Windows 8.1, (I had to install GFWL for it to work) I just installed 18 mods that overhaul the textures in-game, and it's just beautiful.
Even though the hype train is rather crowded, I'm on it.

I'd give it a hard 9.5/9.5

Keep on fighting the good fight.

reviewText:
Fallout 3. This is a game that will, most of the time, suck you in with its amazing atmosphere and environments. I say most of the time because, just like the Steam notice says there, it's not optimized for Windows 7. Now I have Windows 7, and I fully played through all the content in this game, and what I believe they're trying to say with that is that this game has a bunch of performance issues. Fallout 3 loves to crash. A lot. As in, it made me press the quicksave button all the time so I'd make sure I wouldn't lose as much progressas I potentially could. However, I did play through everything, and I loved it. In fact, this is the second time that I've played through everything in Fallout 3. I just love the game so much that even the regular crash couldn't stop me.

The very first part of the game is so well done, very immersive and eases you into the game proper nicely. Don't expect amazing shooting mechanics, while it does have FPS mechanics (you'll never used third person camera because of how bad it is for combat) you don't play it for the shooting. You play it instead for the RPG elements, the storytelling, and the impeccable atmosphere the Wasteland offers you. It's grim, it's gory, it's gritty, it is a complete hellhole on a destroyed post-apocalyptic Washington D.C. Many of the landmarks that characterize D.C in the real world are very well replicated here in its ruined and wrecked glory.

The Fallout universe itself is a joy to be in, with its 50's/futuristic quirks, power armors, aliens, big guns that really go BOOM, and freaky mutations. The game did give me quite a few jumpscares when I was caught unawares by some of the wildlife. The V.A.T.S system is awesome as you pick your favorite body part and shoot, complete with guts and gore flying everywhere as your enemies die. Good stuff.

The inevitable question when it comes to this game is: Is it better than New Vegas or is it the other way around?" I would say that even though I slightly prefer New Vegas
date: both are worth playing anyway because it shows both Bethesda and Obsidian's strong (and weak) points. And both are good games in their own right.\n\nBethesda made Fallout 3. And what makes Bethesda great are both its sidequests (which are always more interesting than the main story itself) and its attention to detail in its environments. They love to litter the landscape with information
recommended: each containing a small story or information explaining why that skeleton's standing in that bathroom

reviewText:
Out of any company that could've gotten the rights to the Fallout franchise it had to be Bethesda, the company notorious for dumbing down the Scrolls series, Fallout was once an intricate RPG that focused on character progression, decision making that actually had an impact on the world around you, deep interaction with NPC's and using tactics to overcome tough disadvantages.

Fallout 3 is nothing more than an action game in an open world, with barely any RPG elements at all besides for upgrading your players stats everytime you level up, which have no consequence as to how your game plays out seeing as it's so damn easy in any case, as you basically role play as Superman which allows you to put little regard in thought when it comes to building your character.

The decision making, which is an extremely massive part in every true RPG's soul, has been narrowed down to Good guy/Bad guy" decisions rather than offering you multiple options
date: each which have a consequential impact minor or big that make you feel more involved with the world. The plot
hoursPlayed: is as generic and un-inspired as they come
voteText: a 12 year old could've written this.\n\nIn Fallout 3 there is NEVER any sense of danger

votesTotal: unlike the older games in which travelling was a major risk and each encounter felt like it could be your last. I really hope they're using a better team for Fallout 4 because if it's anything like this dumbed down generic open world FPS it's going to stink

reviewText:
Masterpiece of modern RPG's.

Fallout 3 is an incredible game, although with its flaws. Slightly buggy and prone to crashing, this game is not as stable as you would hope.

However, the general gameplay is amazing, With masses of replayability, Fallout 3 offers something different everytime you start a new game. Want to take an all-good play style and only shoot when you deem 100% neccesary for your own safety? You can do that. Want to kill every last thing on site with no piy or remorse? You can do that. Want to breeze through the story with no care for any of the side quests? You can do almot anything in this game, and I highly reccommend this game because of that.

The graphics are pretty darn good. For an older open world RPG with such a large world size, it has aged quite well graphically, and will still look good for years to come.

I have been playing this game for close to 5 hours on PC, but I have completed Fallout 3 multiple times on Xbox 360. Making the jump onto PC gaming and playing Fallout 3 could not feel better. This game is buggy, but amazing on PC and (obviously) is the platform I would reccomend you get it on (although there is about 30 minutes of bug fixing you have to do yourself, but it is 100% worth it).

Overall, I'd give this game a solid 9/10. Buggy and prone to crashes, but is an absolute masterpiece of modern RPG's.

reviewText: A lot of games make a big deal out of player choice, but few in recent memory offer so many intricate, meaningful ways of approaching any given situation. You fulfill or dash the spiritual hopes of an idyllic society, side with slavers or their slaves, and decide the fate of more than one city over the course of your postapocalyptic journey through the Washington, DC wasteland. Your actions have far-reaching consequences that affect not just the world around you but also the way you play, and it's this freedom that makes Fallout 3 worth playing--and replaying. It's deep and mesmerizing, and though not as staggeringly broad as the developer's previous games, it's more focused and vividly realized.\nGL HF ;D

reviewText:
A great game worth playing, that is if you can first get it to run on windows 7 or higher, the fix is usually in most cases just changing 2 lines in the game's preferences

(a guide for the fix if anyone needs it: https://steamcommunity.com/app/22370/discussions/0/828937546147175081/ )

but some times there are other problems as well. That being said this game is worth the hassle, as soon as I got it running I enjoyed playing through this game, the main story was short but after finishing it you realize that's where the game is truly getting started I mean the map is vast and full of locations for you to explore making it fun having that unknown factor of what can happen and the choices you make are not often black or white like we want it to be and hell I'm surprised at how the game can give me more creeps in certain areas than some horror games can ever do in entire playthroughs. The game has a great modding community but even without it, this game is amazing and I laugh whenever I see my playtime because that is not how much time I have really spent playing.

reviewText:
Where do i start.....

Ive played Fallout 3 since it's release and Fallout New Vegas since 2011 and boy are they great games.
The Fallout 3 story is amazing and the dlc is even better, i just love how you are not tied down to one thing at a time like other games and how you can explore everything and anything all at your own pace.

The only sad part about this game is 60% of the community doesn't know that you need to do a little modding of the game on windows 7/8/8.1 machines for it to run. They buy the game and see it doesn't work when it clearly say's in the store page it is not optimized for windows 7 machines and they still give it a negative review!

The other great thing about this game and Fallout New Vegas is the modding. If you don't like how that tree over there looks well then download the G.E.C.K and move it yourself with the resource editor!. If you don't like this rock that's blocking your path and it seems sensible it shouldn't be there well then open up the console and type in the delete resource command. The one mod i always install with Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas is the invisible wall remover from the Fallout 3 Nexus, I HATE when they add pesky invisible walls that hinder you're ability to be able to climb a mountain and get out of danger or to climb over an obstacle.

In short Fallout 3 and Fallout New Veags are the 2 best games i have played in my life!. I would even go full out and buy all of the Fallout Memorabilia i can find.

reviewText:
Almost 150 hours later, I feel like I have only scratched the surface of this game. No matter where I go, there are always new locations I have never visited before, waiting to be discovered and explored. These places may contain  a few enemies and definitely some loot, but the most important features within them are those little stories conveyed through tapes or, even better, the place itself, that expand the lore and that let me immerse myself in the year 2277 of this very special alternative universe. This was the game that introduced me to the world of Fallout and to Bethesda, and you can tell by the way it trapped me on my first playthrough. Bethesda knows how to turn minutes into hours without you realizing it, and this game can do just that… even after playing it for a second time.

It’s just… the post-apocalyptic feel, walking through a destroyed DC, entering for the first time in places like Megaton, Underworld or Rivet City, listening to Three Dog and all the amazing old music on the radio, wondering which decision to make in all the quests, visiting Tranquility Lane for the first time and bringing up your Pipboy, seeing Liberty Prime in action, shooting people while listening to the Andrews Sisters, discovering why Dad left… These are only some of the experiences this game has brought me that I absolutely loved and will never forget.

My favorite, however, is probably the scenic overview just after 101. The intro is definitely one of my favorite of any game. It just works so well. You feel safe, you feel loved, your problems are quite petty and then suddenly *bam* you are alone, stuck in an extremely dangerous and unknown place and all the problems you had before are pretty much ridiculous now. Great story telling right there. There are, of course, some things that make much less sense, like your father walking through the wasteland alone and not getting hurt, specially since the player can’t walk 10 steps without being attacked by massive monsters and crazy raiders. But yeah, that’s something we can easily forgive.

And oh boy, the moment I discovered mods my whole fallout experience changed drastically. Imagine being able to modify the game just how you want it. Got it? Well, you can do just that! Among all the amazing mods out there, I really recommend GNR enhanced, which adds a ton of cool music and lines to the game, and Arwen Tools, which turns the game into a real hardcore survival experience.

As of the DLC, my favorite one was hands down The Pitt. They managed to create an amazing ambience, a lot of gray decisions and intense storytelling. Awesome.

Be ready to invest a lot of hours into Fallout 3 if you decide to start playing the game, and then just let yourself be dragged into its setting and amazing lore. One of my all time favorites. I’d drink a nuka cola quantum in its honor if I could. And I don’t know about others, but I had no problem running the game on my Windows 7... besides the occasional CTD. When running a lot of mods (and even if you don’t), you should really look into the CASM mod. It really is a life saver while playing FO3.

So yeah, be sure to enjoy your stay in DC! And remember: DEMOCRACY IS NON NEGOTIABLE.

reviewText:
I recommend this game to anyone that is a true Fallout fan.

Pros:
Great story, however, it's the same 'Go find ____' story from Fallout 1 and 2.
Highly replayable, mods can extend the game's life.
Includes a great collection of weapons such as the iconic 10mm pistol.
Many enemies return in their three dimensional forms.
The atmosphere is dark when indoors and calm when outside.
The combat is no longer, You miss
date:
90 percent of the time, and it is not turn-based.
The downloadable content adds more fun to an already complete game.
The wasteland is a new area not previously seen.

Cons:
The game needs a patch for certain computers to run.
Everything is green, and I mean EVERYTHING. *
The character customization could have been better, all the characters look the same. *
There are so many bugs in this game, exterminators have nightmares about it. *
There are not a lot of encounters in the game.

*: Mods can fix these issues.

The game is magnificent. Of course it could have been more than it became, and surely Fallout 3 did become more than it was when released in 2009 due to the large community of modders who saved this game from oblivion. Fallout 3 is a video game that began Fallout's debut into the modern era of video games, and it is a true Fallout game not made by Interplay.

Final Score: 9.25/10

reviewText: Definately one of my most favorites, and though the story isn't the BEST around, it was more than interesting, for me, atleast. The game mechanics were incredibly easy to use, and felt very nice, no problems with it. Mods were easy to install, and the game managed to hold it's own, while playing a Windows 7. I especially loved the V.A.T.S. system, along with the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. mechanic, that was especially unique for me. And over all, the game, though not always as colorful as it could possibly be, was most atmospheric, especially creeping in a shopping mart, filled to the rim with bandits, that would not hesitate to blow your head off if you looked at their shoes even remotely funny. Over all, great game, one of the best apocolypse related games in my book.

reviewText: I truely love this game. Anyone who truely knows me would know that I am a huge Bethesda fan. I have played this game for countless hours on my computer and Xbox, and would recommend it to anyone.The reason that I enjoy to play Bethesda the games the most is because they allow you to choose your path to victory, and this game does just that. You are able to put experience into any skill you want, from guns to civil abilities such as barter or science. The game designers really made you feel as if you were in Washington D.C. (the wastelands of it at least), and have given you a very interactive world that you could mess around with. In some cases, you will be given an option on whether to take the good, evil, or even neutral path to complete the quest. All of this comes together to create a perfectly created game filled with heart stopping situations, and relaxing interactions.

reviewText:
First off, if you like exploring get this game, just don't expect great graphics from a game made in 2008

The game that changed the fallout series to date was fallout 3 and boy did it do a great job at the first person open world scene. The stroy is strong with intresting plot twists and turns, fun game play, and a world to explore. The first person is an OK platform, but V.A.T.S allows for a new intresting gameplay mechanic. The real pull for fallout 3 is the type of person you can be, either a ♥♥♥♥ or a saint.

Pros:
Wasteland Adventure
Good Story
Intresting Enemies
Hours of Gameplay
Good Dlc
V.A.T.S
Character Choices

Cons:
Graphics are iffy, but that should not matter if you just enjoy games for what they are
Gun combat is meh, V.A.T.S is the real MVP for shooting.


Overall 10/10

reviewText:
Absolutely brilliant. If you're a fan of RPGs, or you're a fan of post-apocalyptic settings, then Fallout 3 is most likely for you. Set around 200 years after the Earth is devastated by nuclear war, you play the Vault Dweller, who has left Vault 101 in order to follow their father's footsteps and make sure he is still alive.

Of course, it's never quite that simple, and once you are out into the wide, open world, you are on your own. For a while at least. You can go nearly anywhere, do nearly anything, shoot nearly anyone, so long as you can live with the consequences.

Even without the DLC, this game is huge. Adding the DLC just makes it bigger, and offers more unique items, weapons, characters, and storylines than ever before.

This game is very highly recommended.

reviewText:
After playing this game many years later than when it came out, I have to say that I enjoyed Fallout 3 quite a bit, including the DLC. The game itself has a pretty nice story and is actually challenging at first when you have nothing and don't know the controls too well. The massiveness of the open-world and the explroation really contribute to the game's wonder. Like the Fallout series are marked by, there are multiple ways to complete quests and there are quests everywhere. Once oyu get to a certain level you can even get explorer perk which allows you to see all the locations on the map. Go find everything and enjoy the game.

Another thing is that you can mod the game and replay the game in a differnet style in a similar sense to skyrim. You can mod the things you dont like or the bugs and even other major things. I played as a goody-two-shoes in my first playthrough and I intend to play as a villian in my second one. The replayability isn't as great as some games, but with mods and a different play style, one can enjoy the game once again. Overall, a good game people should own.

Rating: 8.9/10

reviewText: Absolutely love this game. I really love the Fallout series in general but I have to say, Fallout 3 is, by far, my favorite title in the series. Then on top of that you add the fact that by using the steam version I seem to be completely avoiding all the crashes on windows 10 that I was experiencing using both the disk version and another digital download. And that is even with my mods installed like normal. Right now, as I write this, the game is on sale through the Holiday sale and you can pick it up for less than half the price of a movie ticket (don't even try and include the concessions they gouge you on in the calculations lol) and rather than an hour and a half of entertainment like you get in the theater, you instead get hundreds of hours of amazing gaming, that beyond being a great post-apocalypse  FPS/TPS also has a great story, with real character development that makes you care about the various outcomes. That is one heck of a deal in my book!

reviewText:
The game had issues in windows 10, it was really hard to get the it to load a new game. If you read around there are a lot of fixes and most of them do not work. I tried so many and I can't even remember now which one helped.

I played Fallout 3 when it came out but I only just now beat it all including DLC and here are my thoughts.

The game was ok, the main storyline and the series of quests that surround it are a little boring.
The game does nail the theme of a wasteland and it was an interesting new vision of Fallout after Bethseda got the rights to the series.

The audio logs kept the game interesting, some were funny and others brought deeper insight into the game. Overall the audio logs helped me enjoy the game and im glad they decided to include them.

[DLC reviews]
--------------------
Operation: Anchorage
The first 15-20 mins of Operation Anchorage was really good. I was thinking while playing that I was enjoying this DLC more than the main storyline. It was a lot of fun to infiltrate the buildings in Alaska and do covert missions. The last part of the DLC didn't live up to the beginning and it wasn't as good as the start of it. Overall it was probably the best DLC for Fallout 3.

The Pitt
I was excited to go to a new location like the pitt but it didnt live up to what I thought it was going to be. It had a questionable questline of what was the good path and bad path. I apparently did the bad path by not stealing the cure even though it made sense to not steal the cure so they can take their time researching it and not having to kill. The arena though was ok but it was way too easy for my character level.

Broken Steel
This had to be the worst DLC for Fallout 3. It was a very generic military base attack. The only good thing that came from it was the Tesla cannon.

Point Lookout
I thought Point Lookout was going to be a cool swamp carnival themed area which it was but the storyline for the whole area was filled with bad writing and the whole story for it was a bad idea. It's just a really stupid story and they wasted a lot of potential for the theme of the area.

Mothership Zeta
AKA the alien dlc, it didnt live up to the idea. It started out strong with a cool escape theme but the whole ship area of quests really sucked. The audio logs were really interesting and got me excited to see if others from the logs were on the ship but most were not and it was a buzz kill. The theme of aliens allows you to do so much and they did so little.
--------------------

reviewText:
Accidentally detonated an atom bomb in the first town killing dozens of people and injuring many within the area.
Lost Karma.
Still had max Positive Karma rank.

-Note: Read the notice, the game is not optimized for windows 7 or later. Unless you are prepared to spend some time figuring out what to do to make it work then don't buy it. I spent around an hour and finally find the right fix with the fallout_default.ini file.

Outside of the optimization problem the game has been very fun. I haven't played too much but so far my impressions have been good. There is a lot to do and the open world is interesting. Side quests are plentiful, weapons and ammo can be found at a normal rate though you may find yourself running out. The best part is, if you have a problem there is probably a mod to fix it.

I highly recommend it if you are willing to take the time to get it running.
There is the occasional crash but if you remember to quicksave a lot it shouldnt bother you.
overall I would say this game is an 7/10 due to the problems with os and crashes

reviewText: Massive post-apocalyptic world and a huge amount of locations to explore. I think this statement best expresses this great RPG that is Fallout 3. The game's story is set in Washington and the surrounding areas. If you like a post-apocalyptic atmosphere, a lot of exploring, shooting, lots of side quests and advanced character leveling, then you are going to love this game. The completion of all main and side quests, finding all the locations and exploring them takes more than 80h (GOTY Edition). This can be done in either first or third person perspective.\n\nScore: 9/10 - I would definitely recommend it!

reviewText:
LONGEST GAME EVER

Jesus Christ.

As with all Bethesda games it is highly customisable. It does NOT run well on PC, needs a lot of patching and it's normally against my rules to vote up a game that needs so much TLC, but, it's Fallout 3 baby.

I would reccommend checking nexus mods and steamforums for a guide on how to really maximise what Fallout 3 can do, but even with that the random crashes still occur semi-regular and are HUGELY frustrating. I imagine that's not going to be a problem with Fallout 4 so I'd reccommend for a first timer just to wait for that.

I want to not reccommend this game for the above reasons, but it's an incredible game.

reviewText:
In truth, I've dedicated somewhere in the range of at least 400-500 hours to Fallout 3 across my life, including the PS3 version. Running the game through Fallout Script Extender prohibits time from being logged, but I've dedicated a lot of time to the Capital Wasteland, and yet I've only completed the story once, never explored evil karma, and have only finished two of the DLCs. There is just such a grand level of exploration in this game that it's hard not to daydream about your second, post-apocalyptic life whenever you're away from it.

Though I found myself hard-pressed to engage in the original isometric Interplay titles, Bethesda's 3D take on the setting brings it all to an atmosphere that's borderline life-like, and was the foundation for Obsidian's New Vegas, my all-time favourite video game. Truly, Fallout 3 was a major part of my childhood, and remains a heartily recommendable action-RPG to this day, though I fear a vast majority of its content will become invalidated with the impending release of Fallout 4 (unlike New Vegas, Fallout 3 does not have the combat, dialogue, and variety to survive a direct successor).

Questlines are sparse and relatively linear, with only a couple of different outcomes for most, and many towns simply don't make sense (a village actually built around a bomb, a civilization made exclusively of children, an underpopulated and undergunned slum surrounded by raiders and mutants). There is limited weapon and enemy variety, and navigating sewers and metro tunnels can become enragingly confusing. However, on the flip side, the action is a gory delight, and all of the environments are lovably crafted down to the smallest of details, even if the world abides by its own bizarre sense of logic.

An easy argument in favour of this game is the modding community- an outlet for solving essentially every negative I have listed. However, it is also a display of Bethesda's oftentimes lackluster game design, and does not help anyone seeking a purely vanilla adventure. Overall, anyone looking for a game that's rich in content variety, solid RPG mechanics and a believable world should likely be pointed toward New Vegas (which I more strongly recommend regardless), but otherwise, this is a nice time sink until Fallout 4.

reviewText:
I recommend this game to anyone that is a true Fallout fan.

Pros:
Great story, however, it's the same 'Go find ____' story from Fallout 1 and 2.
Highly replayable, mods can extend the game's life.
Includes a great collection of weapons such as the iconic 10mm pistol.
Many enemies return in their three dimensional forms.
The atmosphere is dark when indoors and calm when outside.
The combat is no longer, You miss
date:
90 percent of the time, and it is not turn-based.
The downloadable content adds more fun to an already complete game.
The wasteland is a new area not previously seen.

Cons:
The game needs a patch for certain computers to run.
Everything is green, and I mean EVERYTHING. *
The character customization could have been better, all the characters look the same. *
There are so many bugs in this game, exterminators have nightmares about it. *
There are not a lot of encounters in the game.

*: Mods can fix these issues.

The game is magnificent. Of course it could have been more than it became, and surely Fallout 3 did become more than it was when released in 2009 due to the large community of modders who saved this game from oblivion. Fallout 3 is a video game that began Fallout's debut into the modern era of video games, and it is a true Fallout game not made by Interplay.

Final Score: 9.25/10

reviewText:
Fallout 3....       The question is not whether you should buy the game, the question is why you're still reading this review                                         and not buying the game right now.

Welcome to Washington DC, home of completely normal human beings.  Visit destroyed landmarks, flourishing cities, an underground town run by children, an aessload of metro stations, caves infested with mutated crabs, and a hotel converted into a slaver camp.  Here, you can meet all kinds on unsavory figures, from giant, angry, green men who hate militaristic people dressed in futuristic power armor, to a group of militaristic people dressed in futuristic power armor who hate giant, angry, green men.  You can also wield unique weapons, such as the Firelance, a strange incindiary Alien pistol, to a modified vaccum cleaner that can fire ANYTHING. ANYTHING!!!

Oh yeah, please don't hate the ghouls. Why would you hate the ghouls? TREAT THEM AS EQUALS, DAMMIT!!!

Holy craep, I can't even give this game a rating, because whatever the max is, it's just multitplied by ten.
100/10 : 1,000/100 : 10,000/1,000

reviewText: On Xbox 360 I have 100's if not 1000's of hours I got this to remeber my young teen years. My father is a Jedi Knight, two Gods of Legend, and one of the most Boss orgainizatoinless agents to ever live. I remind myself this in every battle and suddenly I understand why i can take a missle to the face and be smacked by a Behemoth (A 15 foot tall Radioactive muscle of Death) and only suffer some blured vision. As well as be in several explosions without a single mark upon my body. Ever time i play this game i rember the smells of youth that are not around anymore as if they were still here because this game takes me back. This is and RPG where everything is wasteland and you leave your mark on the world you can turn on the radio th hear Three Dog tell of your glorious deeds or less that nice activeties as if he was there himself to see. A game were when all is lost you must leave your mark on the world. And at the end of your main objective a slide show starts retelling your deeds across the wastes (Good or Bad) for you to see as well as the effects that would come long after your dead and gone for you to reflect on every decission you made. Will the Lone Wanderer be the Last Great Hope For Mankind and save who you can or the Reincarnation of Death bringing about the second apocalypse and engulf the world in ashes again for your own amusement because you can. The choice is always yours any time any where upon anyone. 10/10 would relive again.

reviewText:
The game had issues in windows 10, it was really hard to get the it to load a new game. If you read around there are a lot of fixes and most of them do not work. I tried so many and I can't even remember now which one helped.

I played Fallout 3 when it came out but I only just now beat it all including DLC and here are my thoughts.

The game was ok, the main storyline and the series of quests that surround it are a little boring.
The game does nail the theme of a wasteland and it was an interesting new vision of Fallout after Bethseda got the rights to the series.

The audio logs kept the game interesting, some were funny and others brought deeper insight into the game. Overall the audio logs helped me enjoy the game and im glad they decided to include them.

[DLC reviews]
--------------------
Operation: Anchorage
The first 15-20 mins of Operation Anchorage was really good. I was thinking while playing that I was enjoying this DLC more than the main storyline. It was a lot of fun to infiltrate the buildings in Alaska and do covert missions. The last part of the DLC didn't live up to the beginning and it wasn't as good as the start of it. Overall it was probably the best DLC for Fallout 3.

The Pitt
I was excited to go to a new location like the pitt but it didnt live up to what I thought it was going to be. It had a questionable questline of what was the good path and bad path. I apparently did the bad path by not stealing the cure even though it made sense to not steal the cure so they can take their time researching it and not having to kill. The arena though was ok but it was way too easy for my character level.

Broken Steel
This had to be the worst DLC for Fallout 3. It was a very generic military base attack. The only good thing that came from it was the Tesla cannon.

Point Lookout
I thought Point Lookout was going to be a cool swamp carnival themed area which it was but the storyline for the whole area was filled with bad writing and the whole story for it was a bad idea. It's just a really stupid story and they wasted a lot of potential for the theme of the area.

Mothership Zeta
AKA the alien dlc, it didnt live up to the idea. It started out strong with a cool escape theme but the whole ship area of quests really sucked. The audio logs were really interesting and got me excited to see if others from the logs were on the ship but most were not and it was a buzz kill. The theme of aliens allows you to do so much and they did so little.
--------------------

reviewText: A lot of games make a big deal out of player choice, but few in recent memory offer so many intricate, meaningful ways of approaching any given situation. You fulfill or dash the spiritual hopes of an idyllic society, side with slavers or their slaves, and decide the fate of more than one city over the course of your postapocalyptic journey through the Washington, DC wasteland. Your actions have far-reaching consequences that affect not just the world around you but also the way you play, and it's this freedom that makes Fallout 3 worth playing--and replaying. It's deep and mesmerizing, and though not as staggeringly broad as the developer's previous games, it's more focused and vividly realized.\nGL HF ;D

reviewText:
A great game worth playing, that is if you can first get it to run on windows 7 or higher, the fix is usually in most cases just changing 2 lines in the game's preferences

(a guide for the fix if anyone needs it: https://steamcommunity.com/app/22370/discussions/0/828937546147175081/ )

but some times there are other problems as well. That being said this game is worth the hassle, as soon as I got it running I enjoyed playing through this game, the main story was short but after finishing it you realize that's where the game is truly getting started I mean the map is vast and full of locations for you to explore making it fun having that unknown factor of what can happen and the choices you make are not often black or white like we want it to be and hell I'm surprised at how the game can give me more creeps in certain areas than some horror games can ever do in entire playthroughs. The game has a great modding community but even without it, this game is amazing and I laugh whenever I see my playtime because that is not how much time I have really spent playing.

reviewText: I truely love this game. Anyone who truely knows me would know that I am a huge Bethesda fan. I have played this game for countless hours on my computer and Xbox, and would recommend it to anyone.The reason that I enjoy to play Bethesda the games the most is because they allow you to choose your path to victory, and this game does just that. You are able to put experience into any skill you want, from guns to civil abilities such as barter or science. The game designers really made you feel as if you were in Washington D.C. (the wastelands of it at least), and have given you a very interactive world that you could mess around with. In some cases, you will be given an option on whether to take the good, evil, or even neutral path to complete the quest. All of this comes together to create a perfectly created game filled with heart stopping situations, and relaxing interactions.

Save your game often.

reviewText:
Fallout 3 is an open-world adventure RPG.

You take the role of a vault-dweller, a survivor from underground who has grown up in isolation from the outside world with a bunch of other people.

You leave the vault for the first time following an internal situation that leaves you searching for a certain person. There are many dangers along the way including an army of mutants, various different critters and creatures.. Everything and Anything will try to kill you. You're thrown into the fray and have to survive and complete quests, objectives and tasks all at your own leisure. If you just want to go around killing and patrolling the wasteland?

Fallout 3 is definately one of the better games of the last decade, not only the storytelling but the actual gameplay and concept is very original and highly immersive.

If you have not played this game, you're really missing out on something unique and special. I could (and have) spent hundreds of hours in the world of Fallout 3, it's well worth it and i recommend buying it whenever you get the chance.

It's my one of my top 3 games of all-time. Definately a must-have.

reviewText:
Windows 8 Fix And 8.1
First
Open up the fallouta_default.ini file in: steamapps\common allout 3\nFind the line:
bUseThreadedAI=0
change it to:
bUseThreadedAI=1
Add another line after it and insert:
iNumHWThreads=2

Then download the Games client from http://www.xbox.com/en-US/LIVE/PC/DownloadClient

After installing the client, set compatability mode to Windows Vista SP1

Finally download the d3d9.dll file from https://www.dropbox.com/s/5ot8tm7szvlnuks/d3d9.dll and place the file in your fallout 3 folder

Haven't had a single crash since doing this, and its been running smoothly.
Tweak as needed
