reviewText:
Easily my favorite game of all time. Yes, the compatibilty issues with Windows 7/8 is a problem but once you get past that, this game is an absolute thrill ride. First, presentation is amazing here, never more have I just wanted to look out at the scenic view of the wasteland when you first leave that vault, as your eyes adjust to the light...and you see..chaos..deterioration. Gunplay is great, addictive, and will keep you going till the end. Side quests are located all around the map, some marked, others not, hundreds of hours of gameplay. Ever since day one, I loved the karma system, this idea of being good, evil, or somewhere in between always intruiged me and because of that I have had many playthroughs of the game. Doing a good run, then getting curious and doing all the evil, devious things, then started a neutral playthrough, then doing another good run, because I forgot all the quests, rewards, and the overall atmospheric changes you can have on the wastes. Which, I also loved, because you can actually make a difference in this wasteland. If you get bored with the playthroughs, there's also a thriving modding community out there with plenty of awesome mods to check out.

You know, some say New Vegas is an overall better game, with its factions, added gameplay, better mechanics, but there is one thing Fallout 3 will always have over New Vegas: That Dark Wasteland Post Apocalyptic feel, something New Vegas didn't really show.

10/10
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A game that will most likely never get boring. Every now and then I still think of its dark atmosphere, its grim landscapes. And don't start with the jokes about 'muh fo3 dark ambient', because it's totally dumb.

I do love the war between the Legion and the NCR too, but the two games reciprocally lack what the other has and are thus both good games depending on what you're looking for in a Post-apocalyptic videogame.

The feels that FO3 gifted me with, are so intense and peculiar that I guess very few games in my life will ever be able to grant me the same (let alone a better) experience.

Finally, I believe as many other people that this game is a masterpiece. I was admittedly a very susceptible adolescent when I first played it so my first play-through was frightening and wonderful at the same time; if you didn't feel the same then it's your ♥♥♥♥ing problem lol

reviewText: So many hours... so much time... so much love... its as they say. War? War never changes... but Fallout 3? It definitly does. Every playthrough, every character, every decision, every plot, every choice, changes the way the game is played. No two people have the exact same experience with fallout, so much so that I find myself constantly telling fallout stories with my friends as if these were real events. Everyone I know who plays fallout, has a story of their adventures, and thats what is beautiful about the game. No two experiences are the same, and it constantly offers the highest replay value and countless hours of mind blowing entertainment. Moral choices, sacrifices, survival, and even a bit of equipment management, this is a true gem that should be in every game library available. Its a game where someone can poor countless hours into exploring this world and universe that has been created, and interact with its inhabitents almost like they were real people. More often then not I find myself feeling guilty, or devious as I made plots for my own evil deeds. Fallout, either as a series or by itself, is a game of the decade, and with its current price, you'd be an idiot to pass it up. War may never change... but fallout? Its a new story every time you start, and its an adventure where you choose the results. No amount of words can do this game justice, and I wish I had connected the game through steam a long time ago.. because you would see over 2,000 hrs of time dedicated to such an enthralling experience. There are few games that have had such an impact, and for that reason it diserves a solid 10/10. And just like war.. that will never change.

reviewText:
Windows 8 Fix And 8.1
First
Open up the fallouta_default.ini file in: steamapps\common allout 3\nFind the line:
bUseThreadedAI=0
change it to:
bUseThreadedAI=1
Add another line after it and insert:
iNumHWThreads=2

Then download the Games client from http://www.xbox.com/en-US/LIVE/PC/DownloadClient

After installing the client, set compatability mode to Windows Vista SP1

Finally download the d3d9.dll file from https://www.dropbox.com/s/5ot8tm7szvlnuks/d3d9.dll and place the file in your fallout 3 folder

Haven't had a single crash since doing this, and its been running smoothly.
Tweak as needed

reviewText: Finished this a few days with 50-60 mods (mostly minor tweaks or aethetic changes), and I must say this game holds well even in 2013.  It took me some time to get into it, as I bought it in july and finished it in december, but once you do get the hang of the game, it's amazing.  Having played Skyrim and Oblivion previously, I will tell you Fallout is the superior game of both of them.  The setting, set in post apocalyptic D.C., is very immersive.  There's very few RPG's that are set in sci-fi or modern places, so this is definitely a gem to anyone who loves RPG but feels worn from fantasy themes.  However, like everything, nothing goes without some gripes.  As much I like guns in an RPG, the vanilla guns seem very lackluster.  I actually had to install weapon mods to add some more customizability.  Number 2 is the game is NOT optimized for quad core CPU's, something most computers have these days.  I can't think of the code from memory, but I had to put in some lines in my FALLOUT.INI to force the game to only use 2 of my cores or else the game would crash every 20 - 30 min. Number 3, is the vanilla character models, animations, and faces are terrible even for its time of release.  If you played Oblivion, those fugly faces are back so mods are essential if you want a decent looking character.   Number 4 --- too many super mutants -- enough said.  Now if you've gotten this far in this review, I will still say that the positives outweigh the negatives because I'm just trying to give everyone a good heads up, and if you managed to enjoy Oblivion or Skyrim, you can ignore half of these 'gripes'.  Everything else is good.  Overall it's a 9/10, so it's worth your money especially when it's $5-10.

reviewText:
War, War never changes. But Bethesda has.

When Fallout 4 Launched, those who survived did so in Fallout 3. When the steam reviews rolled out the community set out across the ruins of the old franchise to build new mods. As 48 hours past, what had been the Fallout community, united underneath the flag of the New Fallout Republic, dedicated to old Fallout values of non-voice acted protaganists and actual RPG elements. As the Republic grew, so did it's age, modders spread east seeking better storylines and Intellegint speach options the dryer mercilless expense of the Fallout franchise could offer.

They returned with tales of a game untouched by Fallout 4's terrible launch that have scorched the rest of the world and a great wall of its mods spanning the Fallout Nexus site.

The NFR mobilized its army and sent it east to occupy the Fallout 4's steam page and restore it to negetive reviews that actually made sense. but across the Nexus another society had arrisen under a diffrent flag. A vast army of Fanboys who had never played an RPG in their life. Forged from the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ communities of COD and just about every EA game, Todd's Legion. 4 days have passed since the Republic held the steam page just barrely against the Legion's fake possitive reviews. The Fanboys did not retreat. across the Nexus the legion gathers strength. Dialoge options release, re-textures come out. Through it all Fallout: New Vegas, stayed open for buissness under the control of it's mysterious overseers obsidian entertainment and their army of rehabilitated fanboys.

You are a reviewer hired by IGN to deliver a review for Fallout 4. What seemed like a simple 10/10 has taken a turn for the worst.

IGN representitive 1: You got the review you wanted, so pay up.
Todd Howard: You're crying about a review pally.
IGN representitive 2: Guess who's community is wakin' up over here?
Todd Howard: Time to cash in.
IGN representitive 1: Will you get it over with?
Todd Howard: Maybe EA kills franchises without looking the community in the face, but I ain't EA. You made your last honest review kid. Sorry you got twisted up in this buisness. From where your review stands, it must seem like an 7/10 run of bad luck. Truth is... The Franchise was rigged from the start.

Parallax Concept
Presents

A
Steam Community
Review

Fallout: New Franchise

reviewText:
Fallout 3 is one of my all-time favourite games, and was one of the first games i got when i started getting serious about gaming back in 2008. The feeling of being in a destroyed neo-50's american world has a great affect on gameplay; to be surrounded by a futuristic twist on what was probably the peak of American culture while listening to tracks of American Swing and Jazz Blues while beating a Deathclaw to death after it surprise-attacked you and made you soil your pants is an experience that will only be found in the Fallout games.

The story of Fallout 3 is very reminiscent of the plots behind Fallout 1 and 2, and whilst i would say that i'd rather see a completely different story to the original games, there is far more story and content to make up for the main storyline which in my opinion wasn't anything new.

This game has allowed me to understand and enjoy an old genre of music that is found constantly played through the Galaxy News Radio station. I can't begin to tell you how many times i've listen to Bob Crosby and Cole Porter.

What this game does best and what i find Bethesda Game Studios to do best at in all their games is atmosphere and the feeling of being in the world that they are trying to portray. They did an extremely good job of capturing that post-Apocalyptic feel that aligns well with the classic games, but there are subtle differences because of the location and the different developers.

Combat is very fun, but not as responsive as some of the best shooters out there, but i'll give Bethesda credit as they are known for fantasy games where there is no such thing as fast fire-rate guns, since this is there first time at making an open world shooter RPG they did a good job at least. VATS is definitely the best part about combat, and the gore is super funny. The reaction i'd make to a super mutant's head exploding after a 32. caliber round through the skull is again one of the perks of playing this game.

There is a split of opinion between the new fans and the classic fans. My first Fallout experience was Fallout 3 but eventually i bought the older games and aced both of them, and i think all of them are great. I love this franchise and always will. I definitely recommend this game if you're new to the franchise, and then move onto New Vegas and then the classics.

Overall, i rate this game a 9.5/10. There is so much to do in this game, from taking in the lore, to the happy-go music, the rich culture and the endless gory fun, you will not go wrong by spending your money on this game.

reviewText:
This review comes at a bit of a strange time as I first played Fallout 3 years ago. Then I tried to get it to work with my current rig and it wouldn't despite numerous attempts at fixing it. I eventually gave up and moved on to playing Fallout Vegas. I did like Vegas (and still haven't completed it) but found I had strong memories of Fallout 3 and kept judging Vegas by its predecessor. Then recently a miracle happened and I found a fix that got 3 working again. I have never been able to put my finger on it but Vegas had something missing from it which Fallout 3 had.

I think its a combination of things really. For a start I found the whole setting and atmosphere of Fallout 3 to be way more apocalyptic than Vegas. Thats probably down to the twisted wreckage of old highways that dot the horizon and vast skeletal shells of long dead cities. It really makes you feel that something extremely bad happened to the world (which of course did). The music varies and sometimes can be hauntingly eerie.

There are a ton of side missions and of course the main story. All that before you even touch the DLC's. The game has many good storylines with some that force you to decide what kind of wastelander you are going to be,

With our world supposedly on the verge of its next extinction event and heightened tensions between some super powers its never been a better time to play fallout and visit the maybe world of tomorrow.

Fallout 4 is on its way. It looks great so far but I expect it will be compared to the earlier games such as Fallout 3.

A most definite 10 / 10 classic title that should be in every serious gamers library.

reviewText:
Since Fallout 4 is nearing it's release date I'll release a review for Fallout 3. Now before I start I'll end the common debate most people have when they want to start playing the Fallout series... DO I PURCHASE FALLOUT NEW VEGAS OR FALLOUT 3? Well since I have both I'll write down the pros and the cons of both games so bear with me for now.
Fallout 3 Pros
+ Very story rich, tells you about the Lone Wanderer and how he/she was born and raised.
+ Is a very beautiful game in my personal opinion.
+ Very nice radio that will keep you entertained while travelling the Washington wasteland.
+ Multiple endings so you can keep playing this game over and over.
+ THREE DOG AND DOGMEAT.
+ Very big atmosphere that's entirely yours to explore.
+ VATS is a wonderful gameplay mechanic that is introduced in Fallout 3.
+ Karma meter which makes you feel like you're an actual person instead of just a mindless killer.
Fallout 3 Cons
- No iron sight aiming.
- Not optimized for Windows 7 or later. (This doesn't mean that it's unplayable on Windows 7 it's just that you have to modify the game files and that's really time consuming. Took me about 7 hours to fix Fallout 3 for my Windows 7 computer.)
- Somewhat small level cap (20, but can be increased with the Broken-Steel DLC)
- Very short main story line.
- Companions AREN'T invincible.
- Doesn't have an indicatior for when weapons are really worn thus making them more likely to jam.
Now that I've talked a bit about Fallout 3 I'll talk about the pros and cons of Fallout: New Vegas
Fallout: New Vegas Pros
+ Iron sight aiming.
+ VATS is a returning feature in Fallout: New Vegas.
+ Companions are invincible.
+ Hardcore mode is an option for all you hardcore fans out there.
+ Runs fine on Windows 7 and later (managed to run it on my terrible computer at a stable 60 FPS.)
+ A better radio than Fallout 3 (in my personal opinion.)
+ Weapon modification is an option.
+ REX.
+ You're in Las Vegas, what more do I need to say?
+ Some fun gambling to do in The Strip if that's your thing.
+ Increasing level cap if you have DLC installed. (Increases by 5 for each DLC, 30 is the base level cap.)
+ Very big and beautiful world, but not as big as Fallout 3.
+ The Kings.
+ No karma requirements to recruit companions.
+ Reputation for factions.
Fallout: New Vegas
- Tons of invisible walls over the Mojave Wasteland.
- No back story AT ALL about our player character: The Courier.
- Very limited story endings.
- A lot of walking must be done unless you have found some places to fast travel to.
- TONS of bugs.
- A.I isn't as good as in Fallout 3.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now for the review of Fallout 3: You start off as a baby that is newly born. You then have a time skip to you as a toddler, and another to when you're 10, and 15. Finally when you're 18 the game really starts. This game is beautiful the moment you step out of Vault 101 and see the sunlight for the first time. It's not too far into the game when you meet Dogmeat, a fan favourite companion loved by all. During this time you are already free to do as you please and explore the Washington wastelands. This game is entirely based by your actions so it's amazing that you get to choose how the game will end. Will you be a villian feared all across the wasteland? Or will you be the guardian angel of the wasteland? If you want to find out... BUY THIS GAME! (Ps. took me about an hour to write, enjoy XD)

reviewText:
If there is any game I could recommend, it would be this one. The things that got me were the:
- Epic Storyline where you define the world around you
- Awesome FPS gameplay combined with RPG elements, creating a diverse and interactive world
- Make your own war, do what you want when you want
- The end is never... even at the end, you can continue with the epic world!
So trust me, this is a game you will never regret buying

reviewText: The hallowed memories of yesteryears games makes the Fallout tradition a challenging project to have undertaken. Bethesda has not released a perfect game, but there is no doubt in my mind that this is indeed a worthy heir to the Fallout lineage. What it has lost by leaving the 3rd person isometric view it has gained back 100 fold by an amazingly detailed world, storylines that go far beyond simple lines of dialog, and many different paths for the player to choose. There is in fact far more content than any single playthrough needs to experience, promising greater replayability.A masterpiece.

reviewText: The main story of FO:3 is laughably bad, but the miracle of FO:3 is that you will never realize how bad it is while you are playing it. When FO:3 is talked about as one of the best games ever made it's not because of the main story, it’s everything else. The depth in quests and even unmarked quests, the interactions with other wastelanders or sometimes even just interactions with the ruins of Post-apocalyptic D.C. completely outshines the main story. FO:3 is so good because the emphasis of the game isn’t on some planned-tourist-guide of the wasteland instead it’s on what you want to do –whatever you want to do.

reviewText:
WHO WANTS TO KNOW HOW TO MAKE RED VELVET CUPCAKES?

350g (2 1/3 cups) plain flour
2 tablespoons cocoa powder
1 teaspoon bicarbonate of soda
1 teaspoon baking powder
315g (1 1/2 cups) caster sugar
250ml (1 cup) buttermilk
185ml (3/4 cup) vegetable oil
2 eggs
3 teaspoons red food colouring
2 teaspoons white vinegar
Dollar Sweets Fairy Fives sprinkles, to decorate frosting
250g pkt cream cheese, at room temperature
100g butter, at room temperature
195g (1 1/4 cups) pure icing sugar, sifted
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
Select all ingredients

Preheat oven to 180°C. Line eighteen 80ml (1/3-cup) capacity muffin pans with paper cases. Sift the flour, cocoa powder, bicarbonate of soda and baking powder into a large bowl. Stir in the sugar.
Step 2
Whisk the buttermilk, oil, eggs, food colouring and vinegar in a jug until combined. Make a well in the centre of the flour mixture. Add the buttermilk mixture and stir until just combined.
Step 3
Divide the mixture among the prepared pans. Bake for 20-25 minutes or until a skewer inserted into the centres comes out clean. Transfer the cupcakes to a wire rack to cool completely.
Step 4
To make the cream cheese frosting, use an electric beater to beat the cream cheese, butter, icing sugar and vanilla in a bowl until smooth.
Step 5
Pipe the icing over the cupcakes and top with the sprinkles.

reviewText:
Ridiculous Amounts of Fun

I purchased this game on a whim. After playing FO3:GOTY on my PS3, I was curious to see what it would be like to play on the PC. I was not disappointed. I had some trouble running the game at first, as this is not optimized for Win10, but after some fiddling around I was able to play with great stability.

The only thing I didn't really care for was the lengthy intro. This game is a great way to kill time, and sit back. If your specs are good this game will look amazing. If your like me, and prefer preformance, this will look even better. The combat system is simple, no different than FNV. V.A.T.S. is OP if your stats are right, the weapons and armor are balanced, along with the items. And the soundtrack is nothing to scoff at.

There are many ways to play the story. You can play as a theif by stealing everything in sight (say bye-bye to your karma!), you can play as a hero, a monster, and much more.

Score:
-Gameplay: 8/10
-Sound: 7/10
-Combat: 10/10
-Graphics: 9/10
-DLC: 8/10
-Overall Score: 8/10

On to the technical stuff. All I own is a Surface Pro 2, and some accessories for it. So of course gameplay isn't going to be stellar. I am posting these as a reference for anyone who would like to see what my specs are compared to theirs.

First, the game isn't optimized for Windows 7, as stated in the Store Page, but this is so ♥♥♥♥ing stupid I can't even. They release the game and give 0 ♥♥♥♥s about the new systems where people will try to run their game (that isn't even that old to begin with)? So, I have to go through the trouble of fixing the game myself so I can play it. And what a game.\n\nIt was kinda fun at first but it grew boring and repetitive pretty quickly: same scenarios, same enemies all the time, same press V and aim for the head and blow their heads off quickly to be done with that" over and over again
date: with no new ♥♥♥♥ whatsoever to help make the combat more interesting as the game progressed. The side-quests are boring and if you only go for the main-quests you'll be done in a few hours. The map is gigantic with many "points of interest" you can find
recommended: but it's pretty ♥♥♥♥ing the same desert over and over again with the same monsters and with absolutely nothing to do. I mean it. The side-quests
hoursPlayed:
main-quests and DLC quests can't even cover one third of the whole map. You're left with no motivation to go exploring the rest of the game since there's nothing to do there and you will be bothered by enemies over and over again and engage in dull combat. Again.

The characters are so ♥♥♥♥ing basic I could probably kill everyone and not feel a thing. Actually the best part of this game is killing innocent people (although I always went for good karma so I saved the game before killing everyone and loaded it when I was satisfied). reviewText:
Possibly the most immersive game I have ever played. My theory as to how it was made is like so. The good folks at Bethesda started out with the delicious ice-cream of the clean and efficient movement and shooting controls (most of the time), they added some of the chocolate topping of a fantastically written backstory and an engaging plotline. Finally they added arguably arguably the best part, some of the delightful mini-marshmallows of LIAM NEESON, yes that's right, LIAM NEESON!

To summarise, to say that Fallout 3 is not good would be like saying that Krispy Kreme Donuts don't taste nice or that the Bill's hat looks terrible.

BUY IT NOW!
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's got some nice gameplay and it's generally quite fun. You can find yourself wandering around the wastes for hours, never getting bored.

However, it does have some issues:
- The random encounters can be annoting if you're not expecting them, especially the Enclave ones.
- The lack of aiming down sights annoys me and makes it hard to aim, but some people may think otherwise or appreciate the challenge.
- Unfortunately, Bethesda dropped the ball when it came to the plot, which is silly most of the time and stupid at its worst. The only good thing about the plot is Liam Neeson.

However, I would still recommend Fallout 3 for its wonderful gameplay and the fact that you can play it again and again and never get bored.

reviewText:
My review is NOT based on the quality of the game.  Let's be clear; Fallout 3 is one of the greatest games ever made.  It's up there with things like Half Life.

My review is for this specific version of the game, which happens to be unplayable.

My computer is an i5 3.4ghz with 16g ram and a GTX660 operating on Windows 7.  The game freezes every 5 mins or so.  I've been through multiple solutions from rewriting the .ini file to downloading patches and supposed fixes.  I would still give this game a thumbs up if any of those options worked, but they haven't.  I still can't play the game because I have to alt+ctrl+del and force close the program every few minutes.  A game from Steam should be playable right out of the box, especially a relatively recent (and massively popular) game like Fallout 3.  Steam really screwed the pooch on this one.

Until they fix the freezing, I can't recommend that you buy this game.

reviewText:
[This review does contain spoilers. I mean, this game is 7 years old after all.]

You probably know all about this game. It came out a pretty long time ago, 2008 to be exact. Even though this is the GOTY version, I won't be reviewing the DLCs.

So, let's start with a bit of history you probably already know. Fallout is an action RPG. Fallout takes place after a nuclear war between 'Murka, China and the Soviet Union, which started and ended on the same day. The nuclear war turned the entire world into a wasteland. Fallout from the beginning wasn't a Bethesda game. It was originally a series from Interplay and Black Isle Studios, planned as a successor to the game Wasteland.

Fallout 1 and 2 are considered classics and were critically-acclaimed. Interplay later published the two major spin-offs, the favorable Fallout Tactics, and the unfavorable Fallout: Brotherhood of Steel. Then we got Warfare and Van Buren, but let's not speak about those.

Bethesda later bought the series and developed Fallout 3. They later acted as publishers for the next game, New Vegas, which was developed by Obsidian Entertainment.

Most gameplay would be impossible without the Pip-Boy (also present in the previous games) which is a device worn on the player's forearm, which displays the inventory, the quest log, stats, the map, item properties, a radio and even a Geiger counter which can be viewed in the upper right corner. The standard color of the Pip-Boy is Green, but you can change it to your liking. The color of the Pip-Boy also affects the HUD which displays health, action points, and a compass. Fallout 3 also has perks, which were in previous Fallout games. Vault Boy is the mascot and appears on most things, such as when picking up an item, when you're poisoned or when picking a perk.

The starting place is Vault 101, where the player was born. It is a safe haven from the nuclear wasteland, where people can live in peace and prosperity. Vault 101 is one of the only vaults left standing since most vaults were desimated by vicious experiments done by the Vault Overseers and personnel. Such as Vault 87, where citizens were transformed into hideous, deformed mutants. The game takes place in the areas in and around Washington D.C. DLCs also take you to Alaska, Maryland, air force bases, and even a mother♥♥♥♥ing spaceship.

Bethesda ♥♥♥♥ on the lore quite a bit in this game, but it's not really much of a bother when it comes to enjoyment. One faction has been the center of this complaint, the Enclave. The Enclave are the remnants of the US government, and are usually considered the ''bad guys''. They were supposedly eradicated in Fallout 2. The faction was only present on the West Coast, but somehow the Enclave appears on the East Coast....?

How does this possibly work out? How does mere remnants of a faction travel across one of the world's largest landmasses, without succumbing to the dangers of the Wasteland? They aren't even supposed to exist in the first place. They are quite powerful in Fallout 3 aswell, even proving a challenge for the other faction, the much more established Brotherhood of Steel, which are usually counted as the ''good guys''. They're all for freedom, liberty, you know the deal. That's another faulty trait in Fallout 3, it's extremely black-and-white morally. There's a bad side and a good side, and even though the game makes a meek attempt to change this slightly at the end of the game (the option to infect the water with FEV), it still hovers over the game like a gray cloud of blandness.

The appearance of the Enclave on the East Coast is just roughly and slovenly explained in one of the DLCs, Broken Steel. It was just like Bethesda slapped a book in your face and said: ''This is how it is. Deal with it''. It just doesn't make sense. Many appearances of non-East Coast tech either remain unexplained or badly explained. It makes me believe that Bethesda didn't even inquire with loremasters at Interplay or Black Isle. Even after researching the lore, I have found cracks in the lore that lack any explaination or meaning.

Fallout 3 is saturated with plotholes and inconsistencies. Where do people get their food for instance? There seems to be food in abundance, but I can count the number of farms or crops in Fallout 3 on one hand. Surely the food from before the war would've run out a good 200 years after the war? Oh, and the Super Mutants can keep the mighty Brotherhood stalled, but can't defeat a village of young unarmored adults protected by a small wooden barricade.

The sacrifice" of your father in the purifier is such a forced plot element

reviewText:
Fallout 3, My oh my. I've been meaning to do this review for quite some time, never got around to finishing until now.
Your in a post-apocalyptic world filled with radiation monsters and every minute is key for survival.

PROS

+Almost Too much to do.
And when I say there is too much to do. I mean there is soooo much to do you'll have to put things in a hat to decide what to do first.

+Modding
This game can be modded to infinity making heaps of replayability and even with some really unique mods.

+VATS
I've heard of a lot criticism when it comes to VATS but I actually really enjoyed (mostly because I have terrible aim.) I thought it brought a lot of strategy then your typical FPS.

+DLC!
If you get the GOTY edition you get 5 DLC all with there original story-line and even MORE stuff to do!

CONS

-Slow
Now I get that this game is set to be in a wasteland and that it's meant to represent the emptiness in that but seriously, without Quick-travel I don't think I could have completed it. (Atleast Oblivion/Skyrim had horses)

-Dat Ending
No spoilers here but that ending was less fufilling than a happy meal at Mcdonalds

-Optimization
Not really a con but this game doesn't play nice with Windows 7. there is an easy way around it though.

FInal Notes and Score

-This game has been out for so long and been praised i'm surprised if you still haven't played this game. GO GET IT.
-I haven't played it but most people would agree that New Vegas is much better than Fallout 3.
-This game has a total of 73 Hours with the Main Story and Extras and a whopping 107 Hours if your completionist. Is that something worth your money? Yes.

Final Score: 8.5/10

reviewText: To review Fallout 3 or New Vegas is a difficult challenge. Not because their content is too hard but their expectations of what players want to enjoy are different. While seemingly similar in their mechanics, both games diverge in what players expect to enjoy in a Fallout" game.\n\nI cannot say I regret my  30+ hours of F3 because it led me to appreciate NV. This game was my introduction to Fallout. However
date: I cannot say it's a good "role-playing" game for what it offers
recommended: and I'll hopefully explain why.\n\nThis preface information is to ask that you should take any review of F3 with information regarding the player's history of Fallout. More often fans of either game will fall back on arguments of Bethesda messing with the lore or how old fogies don't like innovation. If I reference NV it's because those similar mechanics were changed for the better
hoursPlayed:
and reasons given as to why F3's mechanics are horrid.

I aim to explain why Fallout 3 is a bad "role-playing" game by the only objective aspects of a game: The Mechanics. You be the judge of whether the game is redeemable for what it does and does not offer.

"Memories Are Made of This..."
Although I want to avoid the plot
voteText: I do want to bring up F3's means of storytelling and of motivation because it differs from NV.\n\nF3's benefit/vice is its more personal approach of the Player and the father
helpfulPercent: James. The intro sequence
votesHelpful: while repetitive for later playthroughs
votesTotal: goes to show how great F3 can be when it develops smaller
votesFunny: personal areas. You can read conversations about the Overseer's dictatorship's effects through a poem or medical notes
commentsCount: or you can overhear dialogue that explains things further. It also contextualizes S.P.E.C.I.A.L. and Perks in-game
column16: and provides an easy means for players unfamiliar with FPS/RPG hybrids plenty of time to ease in.\n\nThat last statement is important because the hour-long intro does its job of hooking the player for the long run
column17: especially in an open-world environment. Even if you don't like James
column18: searching for someone familiar in a hostile wasteland is a good motivaton to explore.\n\nUnfortunately
column19: that attention to detail is not reflected for the rest of the game.  There are areas like the simulation of Vault 112 and a few notable set pieces and landmarks that are memorable
column20: but the majority of places to explore are one-stop fairs for quests and loot. The world of Fallout 3 feels very dead
column21: and not for the atmosphere.\n\nIf the game is played as a one-time commitment
column22: then why do people replay the game? The simple answer is that hidden caches
column23: the ability to go anywhere from the beginning of the game. and the level-design of D.C. are all more interesting than the Mojave.  Being set at the start in the center with no overall scalling of enemies allows the player the freedom to find caches and bonuses.\n\nI wouldn't say the game is designed for speedrunning
column24:
but it's how the player feels like the roads they travel are their own that leaves these players satisfied of the memories they make. That is Fallout 3's strongest-suit.

You're Not S.P.E.C.I.A.L
On the flipside
column25: F3's mechanics for role-playing are either shallow of your decisions or absolutely broken. The main problem is that for whatever character build you want to make your characters they will end all the same.\n\nThe first major offender are the S.PE.C.I.A.L. stats themselves. You are given far too many to be a jack-of-all-trades with no issues. And if you want more points as you play you can invest into them with a Level Up or by finding Bobbleheads
column27: some stats are arguably superior to others. Investing into Intelligence is always superior because you will earn more skill-points with each level (15 - 20)
column28: which in turn can be used to level up your stats faster. And when you level up
column29: you can also choose perks that mainly increase two stats by five points each
column30: or you can choose perks that may offer something slightly interesting. By level 10
column31: I had accumulated enough points to max out two or three stats to 100.\n\nThe problem with this system is that the game expects you to max out specific skills because some content can only be accessed by improving the stat. Because there are no skill magazines (like in New Vegas) or various tools to supplement skills like Lockpicking
column32: Explosives or Science you will invest your skill points into all of them so you don't feel like you're gated out of content.\n\nUnlike NV
column34: leveling up takes more time to achieve but you'll make about as perfect of a character well before you reach max level. This issue mainly comes from F3's uninteresting perk-systems where as NV focused on character-building perks.\n\nA few starter examples of  NV's perks include Wild Wasteland's wacky antics
column35: the skilled but not experienced perk
column36: or something as simple as Four Eyes that gives a character with glasses +1 Perception. Perks in F3 will give you ten points for two skills
column37: others may give you a few wacky effects
column38: and even one will give you fifteen points per each level. They don't shape or define your character—they just make your stats better.\n\nI could delve further about weapon stats affecting damage and spread
column39: but each game handles it similarly. I personally find it stupid for a stat to affect gun-damage. (Swordsmanship in TES can be rationalized by physical capabilities; bullets should not be affected by player stats.) However
column40:
I think my point had been made and it can be simply said that the leveling up system of F3 feels more like I'm playing a game rather than making meaningful character choices.

Goody-Goody or Douchy-Douchy?
Some may not consider builds or the "role-playing" of "role-playing games" that important when it comes to the decisions you can make. After all
column41: shouldn't your actions matter more than whatever you define yourself as? F3
column43: restricts your choices in such an arbitrary manner in what should be a morally gray world.\n\nThe extent of your choices are often in a good
column44: neutral or evil response. It would be unfair to criticize F3 for lacking the factions' system of NV. Bethesda was focused on building the game from the ground up
column45: and NV had the time to flesh out its systems. This morality doesn't excuse how blatant the choices you make are for goody two shoes or for heartless a-holes.\n\nGroups such as the Brotherhood or Enclave are portrayed in such a manner. Quest-outcomes
column47: result in a good or bad result. And because the storyline is a linear set of objectives that have no bearing on your actions
column48: the extent of your decisions feels pointless except for when you reminisce for what you have done. None of these aspects are as bad as the Karma system.\n\nThe Karma system in both F3 and NV is either a hypocritical or broken mess that should enforce player's actions as consequences. Instead
column49: the whole system feels more like a joke. If you kill a certain type of "bad guy"
column50: you will receive good karma. Kill a whole town by blowing up an atom bomb? Don't worry
column51: you can pay off your Karma dues by giving purified water to a homeless guy.\n\nThis system lacks any bite or long-lasting effects to enforce any lessons to learn except not to be a d0uche to others. If there were more risk-rewards associated with the good or bad options
column52: such as the Giant Ant quest where if you don't harm the queen you get a bonus to strength or perception
column53:
then the binary outcomes could mean something more so than a bland morality in place.

"... I Just Want To Start A Flame in Your Heart."
If you want a Fallout experience that revolves around exploration
column55: then F3 is okay at best. However
column56: if you are looking for something with more "role-playing" elements
column57: then F3 will disappoint you as its mechanics are not thought-out.\n\nIf you did not find F3 interesting or NV as engaging
column58: I am hoping that this review will spark curiosity to visit the Mojave."

reviewText:
Mmmm Fallout 3....Where to start. Ok so I bought this game on PS3 and Xbox 360 the year it came out which was 2008. Played the hell out of both of them. Then they started releasing DLC and it got even better. Fast forward about a year or so to when I got my first gaming PC. Bought the game again, this time Game of the Year Edition. Was blown away again from 60fps and no lag at all.

The game revolves around a teenage kid (you) who is searching for their father in the wide open wasteland of DC. There are over 100 locations without DLC and even more with it. The game should take you 40-50 hours first playthrough if you are just a casual player. However if you're a completionist like myself, then you'll probably be playing for around 100 or so hours. There are tons of things to do in this game with and without mods/dlc. Thats the joy of it, each playthrough will be different. On one character you might focus more on melee weapons while you might focus on guns on another. This is one of the only games that I'd truly rate a 10/10.

I read some reviews and some people were saying DAE WINDOWS 7/8 DOESNT WORK" I laugh at these people because they are either not tech savvy at all or just being ridiculous. I have had windows 7 for 3+ years and windows 8 since release an I have not had a single problem at all. The game has only crashed a handfull of times in ovver 5 years. Its kind of sad how people are being lied to with the reviews. This game runs perfectly fine. This game is well worth the money even today. This game still competes with Skyrim and is one of the most Amazing games I have ever purchased.

So overall this game deserves a 10/10 and is a "Must Play""

reviewText:
After spending hours in this game and many more to come, I can easily say this is one of the best gaming experiences I ever had. You play as a child, living in the vault with your father. But one day your father leaves and you leave the vault looking for him in the big wasteland of Washington DC. On your journey you can decide how your character will react, do or what weapons he uses. The world is amazing, almost breathtaking for a wasteland. Not to mention the soundtrack aswell as the character you will meet with be stuck forever with you. The DLC for the game is also great and enjoyable, a little bit too short unlike New Vegas but still very fun. This game is simply Legendary and a must have in my opinion, also a plus is that you can mod it so be sure to check Fallout 3 Nexus for mods.

P.S: Get Dogmeat.

P.P.S: Don't mind the low game time, I'm using a special launcher for modding.

reviewText:
The road so far...

...wasn't kind to me. It was full of loss and misery. Full of hopeless people and lost souls that stepped on this doomed wasteland.

Yet, it wasn't only damnation that followed my steps. I found my father, my love Amata, a faithful companions... only to loose them the next second.

If this was the road so far, what will follow it? I know you can't talk, my good, old, friend, dogmeat. Despite that, I know you can listen, you are the only one who does that. So, thank you, buddy.
________________________

After 95 hours I finally finished this unique game. It was a long journey that, sadly, or not, came to the conclusion.
I have mixed feeling because I can not, but to notice, the flaws of this game.

The combat is far from perfection. Constant invisible walls interfere in the shooting so that stealth and sniper headshot from a far is not an option. It is frustrating at times, but the VATS does a perfect job to overcome the combat flaws. It balances it.

Writing of the main story. It's not good. It's average. It does the job to send you to a different locations and introduce the world, but that's it. I do like the small stories, though, which this world is packed to it's fullest and the enormous attention to detail. But the main plot... At the end, the feeling is that the bone was thrown and if we search enogh we can find it. In any case, sadly, it's not there. A mere feel of a presence of something epic is not what we want.

Don't take me the wrong way. I like this game. It's good. Not perfect but good enough. There isn't any very good highlights but the mixture and huge diversity make this game a unique experience worth to check...if you push by yourself and force to go throw the tedious start that keept me aways the 2 past attempts to play Fallout 3.

First 20 levels are a joy to play. You keep discovering new things and some quite memorable moments. A very simple details engage with a perfection to this unworthy world: A text based story about Grognak that you play on a terminal; Tranquility Lane; Princess who is secretly in love with the leader of Little Lamplight; Brother who got two naughty nightwear; A old man who I saved from suicide attempts.

Despite the average writing of the main plot where it shines is in the clues of the past. There is no history in Fallout 3. Though, it creates an understanding of the past by the logs, terminals and documents. And it does the job like non other game up this date. The contradictive information, the vision of people of the those past events - at times I felt like archaeologist.

There are a huge depth that you can completely ignore and focus on the aspects you like. Do whatever. The world is there. What do you gonna do in it?
________________________
It happened before and it will happen again.
So many killed, so much destroyed... and yet it's not enough, it is never enough. Because war... war never changes.

It is time, we need to go my friend. Our journey has just started.

reviewText:
Muito bom, sério, ficou na média das minhas expectativas.

Fallout é um jogo de RPG que se passa em um mundo pós-apocalíptico, devastado por uma guerra atômica. Seu personagem é filho(a) de um importante protagonista no jogo, e ele simplesmente desaparece e você tem que correr atrás dele.

Claro que, como todo RPG, isso é só a Mainquest, e Fallout 3 contém muitas sidequests para se fazer.

Com o decorrer do jogo, o personagem evolue, assim obtendo pontos para distribuir em várias classificações ( força,destreza,etc) e também colocar perks, que seriam habilidades ÚNICAS, que permitem ao personagem bonus exclusivos daquele perk.

Além desse sistema, há varios, mas muitos lugares mesmo para explorar no mapa do jogo, que por falar nisso, é gigante. Chega a impressionar o tanto de lugares, Fábricas abandonadas, prisões, estações de rádio, a variedade é muito boa.

Há também no jogo, o fator Karma, que guia você para o lado do bem ou do mal,
obviamente você já sabe o que é do bem ( ajudar,suprimir,cooperar ), e do mal (matar npcs,roubar, desrespeitar).


Muitos desses lugares o fator de exploração é usado, pois há materiais como armas,armaduras, itens de cura e alimentação, e coisas quase obsoletas, notas
de pape, canetas, muita porcaria. mas algumas valem bem a pena, pois mostram
, vamos dizer, uma quase quest.

O jogo tenta interagir com você a qualquer momento, NPCs aparecendo do nada, caravanas atravessando, mobs agressivos, as estações de rádio e por ai vai.

No jogo também há facções, como a Brotherhood of Steel.
Apesar de existir facções, elas não são muito concretas nesse sentido.

Exemplo: Se eu for vestido com uma armadura inimiga, não atiraram em mim.
Ou se eu roubar algo ( e se tiver com bom Karma ), não vai acontecer nada.

Dei uma boa resumida de tudo no jogo, há vários problemas também, bugs,glitches, coisas assim, mas nada que tenha me incomodado tanto, só
o fator das facções não serem tão consistentes.

Mas é um ótimo jogo, com uma vasta exploração e ambiente pós apocalíptico, onde sua história é formada através dos seus atos, e o seu ver das coisas.

8/10.

reviewText:
Really fun, satisfying, and worthy follow-up to the franchise.

For all the hate it gets from the purists, it could have easily been messed up so much more by bethesda. You gotta give them cred for getting the atmosphere, the quirky post-60s cold war setting and the exploration pretty much spot on.

I also found the combat pretty damn satisfying, VATS and all.

Yes the story is kind of silly, yes some characters are pretty lame, yes some quests are lacking.

But overall still one of my favourite games.

reviewText: I dislike the fact that the Nexus Mod Manager launcher doesn't send playtime data and achievements to Steam, but I've played at least 150 hours on Fallout 3. I do wish it wasn't as buggy, but the Unofficial Fallout 3 Patch on NexusMods takes care of most of the glitches and bugs. reviewText:
I would highly recommend this game to anyone looking for an open world game with a great storyline to it and the ability to go off from the main quests and do any of the side quests. With Broken Steel, the level cap is raised to 30 and the game continues past the ending of the standard game (which ends the game, no continuing) so a must buy.

The world is full of characters you will come to love or hate and the way you deal with most of these can be from talking your way out of a problem to killing everyone in sight! The different perks you can choose as you advance through levels can change how you tackle problems and can have different outcomes.

Although the store page says that the game is not optimised for Windows 7 and later it runs fine on Windows 8.1 after changing a line in the code (a quick google search of fallout 3 randomly crashing" will lead you to a link which tells you what to add and where to find the file)

Overall
date: Fallout 3 is a fun game with a good story and the freedom to explore anywhere in the game world and the DLC's only add to that experience. 9 out of 10 (because there are a few bugs but nothing seriously serious)\nWould highly recommend!"

reviewText: 1.6 hours doesn't say much, but I've picked this up (again) on PC (after playing 100s of hours on console) just for the modding scene. Sure, this is a hunk of a buggy mess, but that's because this was designed to run on WIndows Vista (and we know how much more steaming that is). Luckily, generous souls created freely availiable patches and resources to keep crashing and bugs to a minimum (which is surprising to hear from a Bethesda game). If you are interested more in map design, this is the game for you. If you are more interested in character and story, I'm pretty sure you should check Fallout: New Vegas. Don't worry, because both games take place in different places in a post-apocalyptic environment, the plot of one game will not reach the ears of the other coast in time to spoil the plot of the other game. TL;DR both games have an unrelated plot as they take place in different settings of the same universe.

reviewText:
10/10 Game, Best Single-Player game so far. Honestly its better than Fallout: New Vegas, but thats my personal opinion.
Simply so much to explore, dozens of game hours to play, modding available on PC providing alot of new content.
I recommend getting the Game of the Year Edition, it includes so much more content for quite low price.
This game is more than perfect for its low price.

The Good:
-Absolutely great storyline and sidestories.
-Very good replay value, you can play the game multiple times. I guarantee it won't get boring fast.
-Freedom to explore what you want, when you want
-Fantastic, intricate quests can be completed in a variety of satisfying/exciting ways
-VATS combat system results in all sorts of tense and awesome battle encounters
-Outstanding art design for the whole world, voice actors, sounds, quests, weapons. Just pretty much everything.
-Exploring, Killing, Looting, Questing. Everything has a mixture of excitement and rewarding.
-Very well optimized, Runs VERY well even of very bad computers. Even a 200e computer can run this solid 60 fps with right settings.
-Very excellent character developement
-Karma system is pretty good

The Bad:
-If you dont like open worlds, or running around huge areas you won't enjoy this for that long.
-Combat will eventually get boring after quite some time (But this is the same for every kind of FPS, cant really be fixed)
-Windows Live creates problems (Can be fixed with using Windows Live Disabler tool)
-Game crashes alot (This can also be fixed with downloading patches and mods)

reviewText: Fallout 3 is a masterpiece.  You get so much freedom. You get to do whatever you want, go wherever you want to go. Do you want to kill everything that moves? You can do that. Do you want to be a more peaceful player? You can do that too. There is so much to explore. There is so many things to discover. Finding and completing quests in the capital wasteland is immense fun. Defeating enemies and collecting their loot never gets old. The story is great. Something I will never forget. From the moment you begin the game through to the end, you will enjoy every second. The soundtrack in Fallout 3 is great. You will get these songs stuck in your head. With top notch talent such as Liam Neeson and Malcolm McDowell, the voice acting is phenomenal. What Bethesda has created here is a perfect video game. But don’t stop at what they give you. There is a very strong mod community that adds even more to the game. Bethesda put so much hard work in to Fallout 3. It would be a true shame if you didn’t experience it.

reviewText:
10/10 Game, Best Single-Player game so far. Honestly its better than Fallout: New Vegas, but thats my personal opinion.
Simply so much to explore, dozens of game hours to play, modding available on PC providing alot of new content.
I recommend getting the Game of the Year Edition, it includes so much more content for quite low price.
This game is more than perfect for its low price.

The Good:
-Absolutely great storyline and sidestories.
-Very good replay value, you can play the game multiple times. I guarantee it won't get boring fast.
-Freedom to explore what you want, when you want
-Fantastic, intricate quests can be completed in a variety of satisfying/exciting ways
-VATS combat system results in all sorts of tense and awesome battle encounters
-Outstanding art design for the whole world, voice actors, sounds, quests, weapons. Just pretty much everything.
-Exploring, Killing, Looting, Questing. Everything has a mixture of excitement and rewarding.
-Very well optimized, Runs VERY well even of very bad computers. Even a 200e computer can run this solid 60 fps with right settings.
-Very excellent character developement
-Karma system is pretty good

The Bad:
-If you dont like open worlds, or running around huge areas you won't enjoy this for that long.
-Combat will eventually get boring after quite some time (But this is the same for every kind of FPS, cant really be fixed)
-Windows Live creates problems (Can be fixed with using Windows Live Disabler tool)
-Game crashes alot (This can also be fixed with downloading patches and mods)

reviewText:
Note that I only have 10 hours playtime on Steam, but I played the game much longer on Xbox 360.
This game isn't optimized on Windows 7, as Steam mentions, but there's an easy fix to Fallout 3's configuration file taht you can find online. This fixes the inconsistent crashes of the game.
Now that I've ENLIGHTENED you of that, Fallout 3 is an amazing RPG. If you don't like sandbox games, don't worry, there's a great quest with markers so you don't have to wander around for things. If linear storylines aren't your thing, you can wander the vast American Wasteland, pillaging shanty towns with an evil cohort, or helping the unfortunate as a lone altruist.
The game's graphics, as some mentioned, aren't state-of-the-art to 2013's standards. However, one needs to realize that this game is from 2008 and using anti-aliasing will fix jagged textures. There are plenty of visual mods for the game outside of Steam as well (no Steam Workshop support for the game).
The optional VATS combat system makes the game turned based in a sense. This is perfect if you aren't a great shooter, or you want to relax more while you play.
There aren't any vehicles to drive in the game, but I don't think that's much of a missing feature because the atmosphere isn't meant for driving around the Washington, D.C. metro area. The Quick Travel function in your map saves you from the fear of having to walk across the Wasteland, so no worries!
There are many trainable skills in the game that will keep you busy, ranging from Equipment Repair, Medical, Hacking, and of course, Marksmanship (not exact names, but in layman's terms). If you've played Runescape or the Elder Scrolls, the skills system is very reminiscent. In addition to this, the Perks system allows you to pick a special trait each time you level your character up.
I give Fallout 3: GOTY Edition a legitimate 100% rating because I find no faults in it, hence my length review.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is without a doubt one of the most incredible games I've had the pleasure of playing. Its also one of the few games I can say I've ever deveoped an addiction to (seriously this game was like crack to me when I started playing it, the first week of me owning it saw maybe 18-20 hours of sleep).  The first time I played it was two years ago on the PS3, and replaying it again on the PC is so much better, mostly due to smoother gameplay and fewer bugs (special thanks to user BenWah for his amazing guide to not only making this game run properly, but the amazing mod community at the Nexus forums that he links in his discussion board posts for this game. Check it out and your experience with this game will be vastly improved/possible).

As far as the meat of the game goes, the story is centered around the quest for your character, the lone wanderer of Vault 101, to find his/her father who mysteriously leaves the Vault and stirs an uproar amongst the Vault-dwellers and the corrupt security forces that govern them. Along the journey you discover a greater purpose for delving into the wastes of Washington, D.C. as you unravel the conflict surrounding warring factions that inhabit the wastes vying for supremacy, whom you will ultimatley decide the fate of.

For those who played either The Elder Scrolls Oblivion or Skyrim, or have run through a story of Fallout: New Vegas, the game mechanics should be simple to familiarize yourselves with. For those new to Bethesda's brand of open-world RPG's, there are light survival elements (weapon maintenace, healthcare concerns, ability to sleep for resting bonuses to stats), a rather sparse but useful crafting system, and a wide variety of stealth and combat options that can be used to fit your own play style (heavier armor slows you down, leaves less room in your weight-based inventory, and impedes stealth abilities, but makes you much harder to kill and vice versa, things like that).

The Karma system does an interesting job of steering which companions you can recruit based on Karmic levels, and steers the outcome of future interactions based on choices made in conversation and dealings with other people. While they usually boil down to black, white, or grey choices, they have an amusing impact on conversations and how the denizens of the wastes react to your presence.An interesting mechanic  that I haven't seen outside of the last two Fallout games is the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System, or V.A.T.S. Costing a regenerating supply of action points to use, it stops time and breaks down the major sections of a targets body and lists your chances to hit each part with your currently equipped weapon. This is especially convenient due to the fact that there is a zoom aim, but no ironsight aiming with anything but scoped weapons (there are mods that correct this issue, but the orginal game is ironsight free) which can feel a lttle disconcerting in the middle of combat for those who are used to the tight gunplay of shooter based games such as Call of Duty, Battlefield, etc.

What is perhaps the most incredible feature of this game, for me at least, is the vast, rich world that from the very first moment you leave Vault 101 you have complete freedom to explore at your own risk. The series beefy lore is expanded and integrated into the game in numerous ways, and is thoroughly fleashed out in documents, audio logs, and items that you can find scattered amongst the ruins of the wastes (if you're into that sort of thing). In almost every settlement there are secrets to uncover and quests to acquire from a desloate bandit hovel to the crumbling ruins of downtown D.C., which can quckly fill your menu into an extensive to-do list. The world itself would be interesting enough to pick through were it devoid of life, but an enourmous and entertaining variety of characters keeps the experience even more engaging, whether you're recovering the last remaining Stradivarius from one of the several Vaults available to explore in the world, assisting the electoral campaigns of the residents of the isolated Republic of Dave, or deciding the fate of the patron deity of a cult of wasteland tree worshipers.

The game has als ohad plenty of post-release support, with five DLC packs that expand the already lengthy base game with several hours of even more questing and exploration. Each pack takes you beyond the Wasteland to decide the fate of a slave colony in Pittsburgh, travel to Maryland to explore a mind bending and dangerous swamp, enter a VR simulation to re-live the events of a key moment in the Fallout mythos: the liberation of Anchorage, Alaska, take the fight against the Enclave further north to Addams Airforce Base to finish them off once and for all, and even miles above the surface of the wasteland to join other abductees in a despearte bid to escape an alien spacecraft. Each pack adds several new perks and weapons that even further enhance the game, and each one can be started at any point of progress through the main story (except for Broken Steel, which requires you to finish the main story before it can be started). Coupled with the incredible support of its dedicated modding community, there are almost limitless variations and user created mission packs to explore and waffle around with at your leisure.

As I mentioned before, the game is among the best I've ever played, and obviously there's something to it given its lauded reputation as one of the finest games of the last generation. If I had to rate this game in terms of a sandwich, it would be a Reuben; a seemingly odd combination of elements that are already pretty great on their own, but when put together, create a wonderful and satisfying product that leaves you hungering for more (and kind of lamenting the fact that you powered through the damn thing in the first place).

reviewText:
It's like Borderlands, if Borderlands were better and a single player experience and actually built up some semblance of an atmosphere that wasn't all just ''sand sand sand epic memes''.

You explore the wastelands and, while there's a main storyline (search for your father), the side quests are honestly where its at. Unlike Borderlands typical ''go to area X, kill things and come back'', Fallout 3 has storylines to each side quest that range from the intruiging to the surprising. The areas were the side quests take you are also areas you'd expect to be part of the main storyline, since they're very detailed and numerous. Seriously, if you only play the main storyline you'd miss well over half of the game, and that's not an exaggeration.

The way in which you find out about quests makes the whole experience feel more realistic. You don't go to a bulletin board and pick quests, rather, you might run into a citizen with a request, pick up a strange radio signal in a particular area, find a note while exploring a new locale, or just happen to stumble upon a fight taking place. It all immerses you into the world and gives it a realistic feeling of exploration and loneliness. Some of the quests also present you with multiple ways to finish them, which means that you get a real sense of added importance to your choices. It got to the point where I was juggling dialogue choices and planning what to do to proceed, as I didn't wanna have one party come to an unfavorable outcome while the other struck gold.

The battle system gives options: you can realistically go through the whole game using only VATS, an RPG-ish system whereby you attack enemies with your equipped weapon; you select a body part of theirs and are shown the odds the attack will hit. Or you can play this entierely as a first person (or third person) shooter. Personally, I found no issue with the shooting, but apparently this is a point of contention as some say its like an attempt at a FPS in an engine that wasn't made for that. I'll say this: it isn't broken and there's nothing inherently wrong with it.

A word of warning; this game isn't optimized for Windows 7 (Vista as well, I think), so you might have issues running it. I simply had to change the ini file to allow multi-cores, and the crashes stopped. But others have had a much tougher time at it, so give it a pirate first.

But issues aside, a solid 9/10 with hours of exploration. I'm 70 hours in and not even halfway through the main game cause I've been exploring and doing sidequests.

reviewText: This game is both my #1 favorite RPG and open-world game. In Fallout 3, you are a resident of a vault; a nuclear bunker sheltering people from the harsh Washington DC wasteland above. When your father leaves the vault for reasons unknown, you curiously follow, giving you the entirety of post-apocalyptic DC to explore. Discover the iconic landmarks like the Washington Monument and White House, or the civilizations that formed after the great war. It is NOT for children. Many adult themes are present, including slavery, prostitution, and drug addiction. Will you be experienced with computers or a savvy pickpocket? Will you use your skills for a righteous or wicked purpose? The choice is yours in Fallout 3.

reviewText:
Fallout 3 - ah the red headed stepchild in fallout series. The elders scrolls: Fallout is a cliche name but so spot on. Also this is the reason while community is so torn about this game. Fans wanted it to be in line with it's predecessor, Bethesda didn't deliver, only used the IP.

Still love it or hate it, Fallout 3 is a good game - IF you like exploration and loot hoarding. But it's a bad RPG - be it cliche story, odd combat or very streamlined stats behind. It does deliver the Fallout series feeling of the nuclear wasteland with buried civilization wonders. You explore the old Vaults and wonder what happened here?

The DLCs aren't really groundbreaking, more loot, more monsters, more mini quests and locations.

Mods are crucial part of this game, especially now when it aged and cause problem on newer PCs and operating systems.
Also they do enchance both combat and too casual mechanics that made game too streamlined and easy. Can't really help with poor and old graphic or with poor role-playing side. Anything else you'll find at nexus mods.

Despite this being a different approach to fallout series I do recoomend it to everyone, especially with all DLCs and various mods that help to customize it to your likings.

reviewText: First fallout game I ever played was Fallout: New Vegas. Some people say that Fallout 3 is better than F:NV some say otherwise. I can't really tell wich one is better. They are both awesome and unique. In Fallout 3 I felt like I was in danger all the time and just fighting for survival. It has awesome story. There is lot to do in the wastelands, lot of enemies and quests. About story... there was lot of sad parts, sometimes even happy... and decissions hard. But one thing is for sure... When you begin playing main quest line, you are going to be very excited to see what happens next, and it will keep you playing. There is also karma. Evil or Good. It might have big impact on the world and also some companions request certain status to be recruited...By being evil, you will make more money, but by being good, people will like you and may even give you gifts. It really is awesome game.

reviewText: One of the best RPG's of all time, just like the rest of the Fallout series. It is also the first modern Fallout title. reviewText:
Literally played thousands of hours of this game. So much replay value. Such a deep and satisfying world. Very well thought out characters who all have their own interesting and unique stories to tell. The wasteland is yours to adventure and you have the freedom to do as you wish.

Also has awesome story line, and side quests, which aren't just errrand courier quests. Every quest is unique and gives you great rewards for the effort and time that they take.

PLAY THIS GAME

reviewerDisplayName: Poor, but can still grind cards
reviewText:
What can I say that countless professional reviewers haven't already?

When I heard that ZeniMax Media secured the rights to the property from the ailing Interplay, I was uneasy, but not quite ready to join the xenophobes at NMA - I'd played more than a couple Bethesda Softworks games, and I'd enjoyed them.

Then I'd heard a lot of wonderful community buzz about FO3, but being the cheap *** that I am, it took a) the inclusion of all the DLC in the GotY edition, and 2) a holiday discount to result in me asking my wife to get it for me.

...and it was one of the best gifts she's ever given me.  Three months of nearly constant play and I'm just a hair from finishing my first full playthrough.  The game is surprisingly stable for a BethSoft creation (elegant & elaborate code, yes...stable? umm...) and I'm looking forward to many more hours of entertainment from all the 3rd-party creations that people have brought about thanks to Bethesda granting us the G.E.C.K.

Join in the fun...

reviewText: Fallout is the perfect example of a game that really brings the player into the wasteland of D.C. The immersion is amazing and has been perfected, it sucks you into the core. The gameplay is exciting and fresh with some repetiton but in a good balance with exploration and fighting. The story is great and the ending is a brillant close. The level of replay value is amazing with so much content even in a single playthrough due to the vast expanse of the Capital Wasteland. Easily one of the best RPGs that has been made and will probably remain as one of the best.
